revision.text:
{{Infobox university | name = | native_name = École Supérieure du Commerce Extérieur | image = Logo_ESCE_2017.png | motto = International in any language | established = 1968 | founder = [[Business France]] | type = [[Grande école]] | academic_affiliation = EPAS, Conférence des Grandes Ecoles | president = Catherine Lespine | dean = Jean Audouard | academic_staff = 62 Full-Time and 220 associated | students = 2,500 | city = [[France]] ([[Paris]] and [[Lyon]]) | campus = [[Urban area|Urban]] | language = English, French | colors = Blue and White {{Color box|#1354d6}} {{Color box|#ffffff}} | website = {{url|http://www.esce.fr}} }}
'''ESCE International Business School''' (ESCE - Ecole Supérieure du Commerce Extérieur) is a business school founded in 1968 by [[Business France]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.esce.fr/business-school/school/history/|title=History - ESCE Business School|last=|first=|date=2017|website=ESCE|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> (French Office for International Trade) and located in Campus Eiffel, Paris. It is a member of France's ''[[Conférence des Grandes écoles|Conférence des Grandes Ecoles]]'' since 2012.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.studyrama.com/formations/filieres/ecoles-de-commerce/actualites/lesce-devient-membre-de-la-conference-des-grandes-ecoles-1157905|title=L’ESCE devient membre de la Conférence des Grandes Écoles|last=|first=|date=|website=www.studyrama.com|archive-url=http://www.studyrama.com/formations/filieres/ecoles-de-commerce/actualites/lesce-devient-membre-de-la-conference-des-grandes-ecoles-1157905|archive-date=2017|dead-url=}}</ref> The school has ~ 2,500 students<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.esce.fr/business-school/school/key-figures/|title=Key Figures - ESCE Business School|last=|first=|date=2017|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> and 9,300 Alumni.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://esce-alumni.hivebrite.com|title=Welcome to ESCE Alumni|last=|first=|date=|website=esce-alumni.hivebrite.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
The school offers Bachelor degrees,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.letudiant.fr/palmares/palmares-des-ecoles-de-commerce-postbac-en-3-ans/esce-bachelor.html|title=ESCE BACHELOR|last=|first=|date=2017|website=l'Etudiant.fr|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> internationally accredited Masters in Management and Summer Programs.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://summer.pariseiffel.fr/|title=SUMMER PROGRAMS|last=|first=|date=2017|website=summer.pariseiffel.fr|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
Among famous speakers, former Prime Ministers Tony Blair,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.laureate.net/NewsRoom/PressReleases/2014/04/Former-British-Prime-Minister-Tony-Blair-Applauds-Laureates-Student-Focus-at-Campus-Eiffel-in-Paris|title=Former British Prime Minister Tony Blair Applauds Laureate’s Student Focus at Campus Eiffel in Paris|last=|first=|date=4 April 2014|website=www.laureate.net|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Jean-Pierre Raffarin, Michel Rocard<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.esce.fr/business-school/blog/ecole/actualites/interview-michel-rocard-ancien-premier-ministre-de-la-france-par-farid-el-alaoui/|title=INTERVIEW WITH FORMER FRENCH PRIME MINISTER MICHEL ROCARD, BY FARID EL ALAOUI|last=|first=|date=|website=esce.fr|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> and Alain Juppé<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.esce.fr/ecole-commerce/blog/ecole/actualites/conference-alain-juppe-comment-panser-leurope-pour-la-repenser/|title=CONFÉRENCE ALAIN JUPPÉ - COMMENT PANSER L'EUROPE POUR LA REPENSER ?|last=|first=|date=22 May 2015|website=www.esce.fr|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> contributed to conferences at ESCE.
The Paris-based business school is renowned in France and Europe for its network of entrepreneurs, who founded some notable french start-ups ([[ESCE International Business School#Notable Companies founded by Alumni|Zenly, Simplified, Sixth June, Interactive Mobility...]]).
== Ownership == From 2001 till 2016, the school belonged to [[Laureate International Universities]], that sold all their French assets to perform their IPO.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/912766/000104746917000224/a2230660zs-1a.htm|title=REGISTRATION STATEMENT UNDER THE SECURITIES ACT OF 1933, Laureate Education, Inc.|last=|first=|date=18 January 2017|website=SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> The school now belongs to [[Apax Partners|APAX Partners]] investment fund,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.laureate.net/NewsRoom/PressReleases/2016/04/Agreement-between-Laureate-Education-and-Apax-Partners|title=Agreement between Laureate Education and Apax Partners|last=|first=|date=19 April 2016|website=laureate.net|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> which owns the INSEEC U network.
== Degree and Accreditation == The school delivers a Master in Management with EFMD EPAS accreditation<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.efmd.org/efmd-deans-across-frontiers/view/751-efmd-awards-epas-accreditation-to-programmes-at|title=EFMD Awards EPAS Accreditation to Programmes at ESCE, Bologna, Chulalongkorn and Salford|last=|first=|date=24 February 2015|website=EFMD|archive-url=|archive-date=24 February 2015|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> as well as French Ministry of Higher Education and Research accreditation. It also cofounded the Consortium of International Double Degrees (CIDD).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cidd.org/about-cidd/|title=ABOUT CIDD|last=|first=|date=|website=www.cidd.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
ESCE specializes in International Affairs.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.letudiant.fr/examen/concours-ecole-commerce/ecoles-de-commerce-concours-sesame-mode-demploi-16450/quelle-est-la-vraie-selectivite-du-concours-sesame-17827.html|title=Quelle est la vraie sélectivité du concours Sésame ?|last=|first=|date=2017|website=L'Edudiant|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> For long it has been the most demanded school within [https://www.concours-sesame.net/ SÉSAME]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://actualites.prepa-hec.org/2008/11/le-concours-sesame-officialise-les-statistiques-de-la-session-2008/0457|title=Le concours SESAME officialise les statistiques de la session 2008|last=|first=|date=2008|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Examination (famous Business School examination in France), of which it was a founding member in 1992.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://actualites.prepa-hec.org/2008/11/le-concours-sesame-officialise-les-statistiques-de-la-session-2008/0457|title=Le concours SESAME officialise les statistiques de la session 2008|last=|first=|date=2008|website=prepa-hec.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
It is renowned for its dual degree<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.hwr-berlin.de/fachbereich-wirtschaftswissenschaften/studiengaenge/internationales-management-management-international-bama-dtfr/|title=Deutsch-französischer Studiengang Gefördert durch die Deutsch-Französische Hochschule|last=|first=|date=|website=hwr-berlin.de|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> with [[Berlin School of Economics and Law|Berlin School of Economics & Law]], often referred as one of Germany's best Business Schools,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.hwr-berlin.de/en/service/news/single-view/article/hwr-berlin-germanys-best-business-school-1/|title=HWR Berlin "Germany's BEST Business School"|last=|first=|date=March 2016|website=hwr-berlin.de|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> as well as its dual degree with [[University of International Business and Economics (Beijing)|UIBE Beijing]], one of China's remarkable Business schools.
== Notable teachers == [[:fr:Jean-Marie Cambacérès|Jean-Marie Cambacérès]] (Associated Professor since 2010) - [[École nationale d'administration|ENA]] Graduate (Promotion Voltaire),<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://iconicphotos.org/2012/03/13/promotion-voltaire/|title=Promotion Voltaire|last=|first=|date=|website=Iconic Photos|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Former Congressman (député), Business Man, President of European & Global Affairs at [[French Economic, Social and Environmental Council|CESE]] (Conseil Economique, Social et Environnemental), founder of ESCE Centre Asie.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.esce.fr/centreasie/|title=ESCE CENTRE ASIE|last=|first=|date=2017|website=esce/centreasie|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Notable Alumni == Alexandre de Rothschild, Chairman of [[Rothschild & Co]] bank.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.lesechos.fr/16/04/2018/lesechos.fr/0301570831726_comment-alexandre-de-rothschild-s-est-prepare-a-reprendre-le-flambeau.htm|title=Comment Alexandre de Rothschild s'est préparé à reprendre le flambeau - Les Echos|website=www.lesechos.fr|language=fr|access-date=2018-08-27}}</ref>
== List of Dual Degree Programs == * BITS – Business And Information Technology School - (Campus Berlin & Iserlohn) (Germany) * Hochschule Augsburg – University Of Applied Sciences (Germany) * Hochschule Mainz- University Of Applied Sciences (Germany) * [[Berlin School of Economics and Law|Hochschule für Wirtschaft und Recht Berlin]] (HWR) (Germany) * [[University of International Business and Economics (Beijing)|UIBE – University of International Business and Economics]] (China) * [[CEU Cardinal Herrera University|Universidad Cardenal Herrera Ceu]] (Spain) * [[Universidad Europea de Madrid]] (Spain) * [[Coastal Carolina University]] (USA) * [[Kendall College]] (USA) * [[Nicholls State University]] (USA) * [[Dublin Business School]] - Griffith College Dublin (Ireland) * [[London South Bank University]] (United Kingdom) * [[Robert Gordon University]] (United Kingdom) * [[University of Brighton]] (United Kingdom) * [[University of Westminster]] (United Kingdom) * [[Nottingham Trent University]] (United Kingdom) * [[University of South Wales|South Wales University]] (United Kingdom) * [[University of Maribor]] (Slovenia) * [[Linnaeus University]] (Sweden) * [[Karlstad University|University of Karlstad]] (Sweden)
== Notable Companies founded by Alumni == Zenly, acquired by Snapchat in 2017 for USD 250 to 350 Million, quoted by [[Les Échos (newspaper)|Les Echos]] to be part of top 10 most expensive french start-ups ever created.
Simplifield, analytics platform for the retail industry, USD 4 Million raised.
Interactive Mobility, entertainment platform for planes and cabs; €4 Million fundraising ongoing.
== References == {{reflist}}

revision.comment: Alter: title, journal. Add: journal. Removed parameters. You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]]. | [[WP:UCB|User-activated]]; [[Category:United States Supreme Court cases]].
revision.text:
{{Infobox SCOTUS case | Litigants = Fisher v. University of Texas | ArgueDate = October 10 | ArgueYear = 2012 | DecideDate= June 24 | DecideYear= 2013 | FullName = Abigail Noel Fisher, Petitioner v. University of Texas at Austin, et al. | USVol = 570 | USPage = ___ | ParallelCitations = | Docket = 11-345 | OralArgument = https://www.oyez.org/cases/2010-2019/2012/2012_11_345#argument | Prior = | Subsequent = See ''[[Fisher v. University of Texas (2016)]]'' | Holding = The Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals failed to apply [[strict scrutiny]] in its decision affirming the admissions policy. The decision is vacated, and the case remanded for further consideration. | SCOTUS = 2010-2016 | Majority = Kennedy | JoinMajority = Roberts, Scalia, Thomas, Breyer, Alito, Sotomayor | Concurrence = Scalia | Concurrence2 = Thomas | Dissent = Ginsburg | NotParticipating = Kagan | LawsApplied = [[Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|U.S. Const. amend. XIV]], ''[[Grutter v. Bollinger]]'' }}
'''''Fisher v. University of Texas''''', 570 U.S. ___ (2013), also known as '''''Fisher I''''' (to distinguish it from [[Fisher v. University of Texas (2016)|the 2016 case]]),<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/15pdf/14-981_4g15.pdf |title= No. 14–981 Fisher v. University of Tex. at Austin |publisher=[[Supreme Court of the United States|United States Supreme Court]] |date=June 23, 2016 |accessdate=June 29, 2016}}</ref> is a [[Supreme Court of the United States|United States Supreme Court]] case concerning the [[Affirmative action in the United States|affirmative action]] [[College admissions in the United States#Race and ethnicity|admissions policy]] of the [[University of Texas at Austin]]. The Supreme Court voided the lower appellate court's ruling in favor of the University and [[Remand (court procedure)|remanded]] the case, holding that the lower court had not applied the standard of [[strict scrutiny]], articulated in ''[[Grutter v. Bollinger]]'' (2003) and ''[[Regents of the University of California v. Bakke]]'' (1978), to its admissions program. The Court's ruling in ''Fisher'' took ''Grutter'' and ''Bakke'' as given and did not directly revisit the constitutionality of using race as a factor in college admissions.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/12pdf/11-345_l5gm.pdf |title= Abigail Noel Fisher v. University of Texas at Austin (Case 11-345) |publisher= The Supreme Court of the United States }}</ref>
The suit, brought by undergraduate Abigail Fisher in 2008, asked that the Court declare the University's race-conscious admissions inconsistent with ''Grutter'', which had in 2003 established that race had an appropriate but limited role in the admissions policies of [[List of state universities in the United States|public universities]]. While reasserting that any consideration of race must be "[[Narrow tailoring|narrowly tailored]]", with ''Fisher'' the Court did not go on to overrule ''Grutter'', a relief for political activists who feared that the Court would end affirmative action.<ref>{{cite news|last=Liptak|first=Adam|title=Justices Step Up Scrutiny of Race in College Entry|url= https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/25/us/affirmative-action-decision.html?hp&pagewanted=all|accessdate=25 June 2013| work = New York Times|date=24 June 2013}}</ref>
The United States District Court heard ''Fisher v. University of Texas'' in 2009 and upheld the legality of the University's admission policy in a [[summary judgment]]. The case was appealed to the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit|Fifth Circuit]] which also ruled in the University's favor. The Supreme Court agreed on February 21, 2012, to hear the [[List of United States Supreme Court cases|case]]. Justice [[Elena Kagan]] recused herself because she served as the Solicitor General when the Department of Justice filed an ''amicus curiae'', or friend-of-the-court, brief in the Fisher case when it was pending in the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. On June 24, 2013, the Fifth Circuit's decision was vacated, and the case remanded for further consideration in a 7–1 decision, with Justice [[Ruth Bader Ginsburg]] dissenting. Justices [[Antonin Scalia]] and [[Clarence Thomas]] filed concurring opinions.
Applying the Supreme Court's 2013 decision, the Fifth Circuit once again found for UT Austin in 2014. Fisher again appealed the Fifth Circuit's decision, and in 2016 the Supreme Court [[Fisher v. University of Texas (2016)|upheld the lower court in a 4–3 decision]].
== Background == Plaintiffs Abigail Noel Fisher and Rachel Multer Michalewicz applied to the University of Texas at Austin in 2008 and were denied admission. The two women, both white, filed suit, alleging that the University had discriminated against them on the basis of their race in violation of the [[Equal Protection Clause]] of the [[Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution|Fourteenth Amendment]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Richey |first=Warren|title =Affirmative action in college admissions goes back before Supreme Court|url = http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Justice/2012/0221/Affirmative-action-in-college-admissions-goes-back-before-Supreme-Court| work =The [[Christian Science Monitor]]|date=February 21, 2012}}</ref> At the time that the initial lawsuit was filed, the University of Texas at Austin accepted students in the top 10% of each Texas high school's graduating class, regardless of their race; under [[Texas House Bill 588]], 81% of 2008's freshman class were admitted under the plan.<ref>{{cite web|last=Wermiel|first=Stephen|title=SCOTUS for law students: Barbara Grutter, meet Abigail Fisher|url=http://www.scotusblog.com/?p=129451|publisher=SCOTUSblog|date=October 11, 2011}}</ref> (Starting with the fall 2010 admission class, Senate Bill 175 adjusted this rule to the top 7 percent, but with no more than 75 percent of freshman slots filled under automatic admissions.)<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.kellerisd.net/community/communications/news/Pages/UT-Austin-Admissions-Policy-.aspx|title=State Adjusts UT Admissions Policy to 'Top 7 Percent'|accessdate=27 September 2016}} </ref>
Applicants who, like Fisher, failed to gain acceptance by automatic admissions can still gain admission by scoring highly in a process that evaluates their talents, leadership qualities, family circumstances, and race.<ref name="AS"/><ref>{{cite news | url= http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/comment/2012/05/the-other-big-supreme-court-case.html | title=The Other Big Supreme Court Case | work= The New Yorker | author= Jeffrey Toobin }}</ref> Fisher had a [[grade point average]] of 3.59 (adjusted to a 4.0 scale)<ref name="JointAppendix65">{{cite web |url= http://www.utexas.edu/vp/irla/Documents/Joint%20Appendix.pdf |title= Joint Appendix, Abigail Noel Fisher v. University of Texas at Austin (Case 11-345) |publisher= The Supreme Court of the United States |page=65a–66a |accessdate= October 10, 2012}}</ref> and was in the top 12% of her class at [[Austin High School (Fort Bend County, Texas)|Stephen F. Austin High School]].<ref name="JointAppendix65"/> She scored 1180 on her [[SAT]] (measured on the old 1600-point scale, because UT Austin did not consider the writing section in its undergraduate admissions decision for the 2008 incoming freshman class).<ref name="JointAppendix65"/> The 25th and 75th percentiles of the incoming class at UT-Austin were 1120 and 1370.<ref name="JointAppendix65"/> She was involved in the orchestra and math competitions and volunteered at [[Habitat for Humanity]].<ref name="JointAppendix65"/>
During the case proceedings, Fisher enrolled at [[Louisiana State University]], from which Fisher graduated in 2012 with a degree in finance.<ref name="nyt"/><ref name=DailyTexanFeb21/> In 2011, Michalewicz withdrew from the case, leaving Fisher as the sole plaintiff.<ref name="AS"/><ref name=DailyTexanFeb21>{{cite news|title=Fisher v. University of Texas at Austin challenges affirmative action in higher education|url=http://www.dailytexanonline.com/news/2012/02/21/fisher-v-university-texas-austin-challenges-affirmative-action-higher-education|newspaper=The Daily Texan|date=February 21, 2012}}</ref>
== Lower courts == In 2009, [[United States District Court for the Western District of Texas|United States District Court]] judge [[Sam Sparks]] upheld the University's policy, finding that it meets the standards laid out in ''Grutter v. Bollinger''.<ref name="nyt"/> That decision was affirmed by a Fifth Circuit panel composed of judges [[Patrick Higginbotham]], [[Carolyn Dineen King]] and [[Emilio M. Garza]]. In his ruling, Higginbotham wrote that the "ever-increasing number of minorities gaining admission under this 'Top Ten Percent Law' casts a shadow on the horizon to the otherwise-plain legality of the ''Grutter-like'' admissions program, the Law's own legal footing aside".<ref>{{citation |title=Abigail Fisher, et al. v. State of Texas, et al.|url=http://docs.justia.com/cases/federal/appellate-courts/ca5/09-50822/09-50822-cv0.wpd-2011-02-02.pdf |number=No. 09-50822 |date=January 18, 2011 |publisher=United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit }}</ref>
A request for a full-court [[en banc]] hearing was denied by a 9–7 vote by circuit judges.<ref>{{cite news|last =Farmer|first=Liz| title=U.S. Supreme Court to hear case on UT admission policies | url= http://www.dailytexanonline.com/news/2012/02/21/us-supreme-court-hear-case-ut-admission-policies| work = The Daily Texan |date=February 21, 2012}}</ref><ref>[http://www.ca5.uscourts.gov/opinions/pub/09/09-50822-CV1.wpd.pdf "Order on the petition for rehearing en banc"], United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.</ref>
== Original Supreme Court hearing == In September 2011, lawyers representing Fisher filed petition seeking review from the Supreme Court.<ref name="nyt"/><ref>[https://www.scribd.com/doc/120389349/Writ-of-Certiorari Petition for Certiorari] Fisher v. University of Texas at Austin. Retrieved June 25, 2013.</ref> The plaintiff's legal team was assembled by the Project on Fair Representation, a [[Washington, D.C.]]-based legal defense fund active in attempts to overturn race-based laws, whose legal fees were paid by [[Donors Trust]], a conservative [[donor-advised fund]].<ref>{{cite news |title= One Man Standing Against Race-Based Laws | last= Smith |first=Morgan |date = February 23, 2012 |accessdate=February 21, 2015 | work =[[New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/02/24/us/edward-blum-and-the-project-on-fair-representation-head-to-the-supreme-court-to-fight-race-based-laws.html}}</ref> On February 21, 2012, the court granted ''[[Procedures of the Supreme Court of the United States#Selection of cases|certiorari]]'' in ''Fisher v. University of Texas at Austin''. Justice [[Elena Kagan]] recused herself from the case and did not participate in the court's discussions.<ref>{{cite news|last=Barnes |first=Robert|title =Supreme Court agrees to reconsider use of race in college admission decisions |url =https://www.washingtonpost.com/supreme-court-agrees-to-reconsider-use-of-race-in-college-admission-decisions/2010/07/28/gIQA2viJRR_story_1.html| work =The Washington Post| date =February 21, 2012}}</ref> Kagan's recusal was most likely due to her involvement with the case while she was [[Solicitor General]].<ref name="AS">{{cite news|last=Haurwitz |first=Ralph K. M. |title=UT's race-conscious admission policy facing Supreme Court test |url=http://www.statesman.com/news/texas-politics/uts-race-conscious-admission-policy-facing-supreme-court-2191410.html |work=Austin American-Statesman |date=February 21, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120429014055/http://www.statesman.com/news/texas-politics/uts-race-conscious-admission-policy-facing-supreme-court-2191410.html |archivedate=April 29, 2012 }}</ref>
''[[Amicus curiae|Amicus]]'' briefs were filed by [[Teach for America]], the Asian American Legal Foundation, the [[Asian Pacific American Legal Center]], the [[Asian American Legal Defense and Education Fund]], the California Association of Scholars and Center for Constitutional Jurisprudence, the Black Student Alliance at The University of Texas, the [[Mountain States Legal Foundation]], the [[Pacific Legal Foundation]], [[Peter Kirsanow]], [[Stuart Taylor, Jr.]], and many others.<ref>{{cite web |title=Fisher v. University of Texas at Austin|url=http://www.scotusblog.com/case-files/cases/fisher-v-university-of-texas-at-austin/|publisher=SCOTUSblog|accessdate=March 28, 2012}}</ref>
The case was on the Supreme Court calendar for the term beginning in October 2012.<ref>{{citation |title=Affirmative action review due next Term |url=http://www.scotusblog.com/2012/02/affirmative-action-review-next-term |first=Lyle |last=Denniston |date=February 21, 2012 |publisher=SCOTUSblog |accessdate=April 6, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Harrop|first=Froma|title=Racial Preferences in College Admissions: Time to Go|url=http://www.realclearpolitics.com/articles/2012/02/28/racial_preferences_in_college_admissions_time_to_go_113272.html|newspaper=Real Clear Politics|date=February 28, 2012}}</ref> There were concerns that if the Court overruled ''Grutter'', affirmative action at public universities would end in the United States.<ref name="nyt"/> Some argued that the result of such a ruling would decrease the number of black and Hispanic students admitted to American universities while increasing the proportion of white and Asian students.<ref name="nyt">{{cite news |last=Liptak|first=Adam|title = College Diversity Nears Its Last Stand| url= https://www.nytimes.com/2011/10/16/sunday-review/college-diversity-nears-its-last-stand.html?_r=1&pagewanted=all| work = New York Times|date=October 15, 2011 |quote= Should the Supreme Court disavow it, the student body at the University of Texas and many other public colleges and universities would almost instantly become whiter and more Asian, and less black and Hispanic.}}</ref>
=== Oral arguments === On October 10, 2012, the Supreme Court heard oral arguments in the case. Bert Rein represented the petitioner, [[Gregory G. Garre]], a former Solicitor General, represented the respondent, the university,<ref>{{cite news |author1 = Leon Lin |title = Fisher v. UT affirmative action case oral arguments heard |url = http://tech.mit.edu/V132/N45/fisher.html|work=[[The Tech (newspaper)|The Tech]] |issue =45 | volume =132 |date= October 16, 2012}}</ref> and Solicitor General [[Donald Verrilli|Donald Verrilli, Jr.]], presented the government's stance in support of the respondent.<ref>{{cite news | author1 = Daniel Fisher |title =Supreme Court's Final Decisions Also A Verdict On SG Verrilli| url= https://www.forbes.com/sites/danielfisher/2013/06/19/supreme-courts-final-decisions-also-a-verdict-on-sg-verrilli |work =Forbes |date =June 19, 2013}}</ref>
During the beginning of the petitioner’s argument, Justices [[Sonia Sotomayor|Sotomayor]] and [[Ruth Bader Ginsburg|Ginsburg]] asked questions about whether the case was [[:wikt:moot|moot]]. Specifically, they were concerned with the university's arguments that Fisher would not have earned admission regardless of her race, that she had already graduated from college, and that she only named the $100 application fee as real damages. [[Antonin Scalia|Scalia]] commented that the harm of [[racial discrimination]] alone created an active controversy under the Court’s previous [[Equal Protection]] jurisprudence.<ref name="trans11-345">[https://www.supremecourt.gov/oral_arguments/argument_transcripts/2012/11-345.pdf "Oral Argument Transcript"], U.S. Supreme Court</ref>
Justices Scalia, [[Samuel Alito|Alito]], and [[Justice John Roberts|Roberts]] asked many questions about the definition of a “critical mass”, which ''Grutter'' named as the central measure of diversity. Scalia started calling it a “critical cloud” after the university’s lawyer failed, upon multiple requests, to define the central measure of diversity.<ref name="trans11-345"/> Chief Justice Roberts asked whether an applicant who was one-quarter or one-eighth [[Latino]] would be permitted by the University to check the “[[Latino]]” box.<ref name="trans11-345"/> Garre responded that the applicant was entitled to self-identify as any race, subject to discipline under the university's [[Academic honor code|honor code]], and that the University did not ever question that determination.<ref name="trans11-345"/>
Legal analysts concurred that the process of oral argument indicated that a majority of the justices disliked the university's position.<ref>Nick DeSantis, [http://chronicle.com/blogs/ticker/argolinkroundups/early-reactions-to-the-supreme-courts-fisher-v-texas-arguments "Early Reactions to Fisher v Texas Arguments"], ''[[Chronicle of Higher Education]]'', October 10, 2012.</ref>
=== Opinions of the Court === The opinion was issued on June 24, 2013—unusually late given that it was argued in October 2012. In a 7–1 decision, the Court vacated and remanded the Fifth Circuit's ruling. Writing for the majority, Justice Kennedy concluded that the Fifth Circuit failed to apply ''[[strict scrutiny]]'' in its decision affirming the admissions policy. Instead, he wrote, the Fifth Circuit held that Fisher could only challenge "whether the University's decision to use race as an admissions factor 'was made in [[Good faith (law)|good faith]].' It presumed that the school had acted in good faith and gave petitioner the burden of rebutting that presumption".<ref>''Fisher v. University of Texas at Austin'', 570 U. S., (slip op., at 11).</ref> Kennedy argued that per the ''Grutter ''ruling, the burden of evidence primarily lies with the university "to prove that its admissions program is narrowly tailored to obtain the educational benefits of diversity".<ref>''Fisher v. University of Texas at Austin'', 570 U. S., (slip op., at 13).</ref>
Justice Scalia wrote a one-paragraph concurring opinion, stating that he still holds the view that he first expressed in his concurring opinion in ''Grutter'': "The Constitution proscribes government discrimination on the basis of race, and state-provided education is no exception".<ref>Casey Scott McKay, [https://a.next.westlaw.com/Document/I782fed6fd7f611e398db8b09b4f043e0/View/FullText.html?navigationPath=Search%2Fv3%2Fsearch%2Fresults%2Fnavigation%2Fi0ad604050000014a91c69b1176609585%3FNav%3DANALYTICAL%26fragmentIdentifier%3DI782fed6fd7f611e398db8b09b4f043e0%26startIndex%3D1%26contextData%3D%2528sc.Search%2529%26transitionType%3DSearchItem&listSource=Search&listPageSource=3ad1ed03bbc61d89f599cd6b138b0d22&list=ANALYTICAL&rank=2&grading=na&sessionScopeId=4bf0fdfe230d3f3dc8af052ad5aa1ce9&originationContext=Search%20Result&transitionType=SearchItem&contextData=%28sc.Search%29 "Fishin' with Fisher: Determining the Depth of Deference Does Not Demand Damning Deference to A Dastardly Death"], 83 ''[[Mississippi Law Journal]]'' 951 (2014).</ref> Because the petitioner did not ask to overturn the holding in ''Grutter'', that there is a compelling evidence in the educational benefits of diversity to justify racial preferences in university admissions, he joined with the majority in full.<ref>''Fisher v. University of Texas Austin'', 570 U. S., (Scalia, J., concurring slip op., at 1).</ref>
Justice Thomas wrote his own concurrence, stating his reasons for overturning ''Grutter'', and ruled that the use of race in higher education admissions violated the [[Equal Protection Clause]]. Thomas concluded that ''Grutter'' was a radical departure from the Court's application of the strict scrutiny test. According to Justice Thomas, strict scrutiny had only been previously satisfied where the state actor was acting to protect national security or to remedy its own past discrimination.<ref>''Fisher v. University of Texas at Austin'', 570 U. S., (Thomas, J., concurring slip op., at 4–5).</ref> He wrote that student body diversity was simply not important enough to override the presumption that race-based policies are unconstitutional.
Additionally, comparing such university admissions with [[Racial segregation in the United States|desegregation]], he wrote that "there is no principled distinction between the University’s assertion that diversity yields educational benefits and the segregationists’ assertion that segregation yielded those same benefits".<ref>''Fisher v. University of Texas at Austin'', 570 U. S., (Thomas, J., concurring slip op., at 12).</ref> He also wrote that he believed that such admissions programs may actually be more harmful: "Blacks and Hispanics admitted to the University as a result of racial discrimination are, on average, far less prepared than their white and Asian classmates...the University’s discrimination does nothing to increase the number of blacks and Hispanics who have access to a college education generally...any blacks and Hispanics who likely would have excelled at less elite schools are placed in a position where underperformance is all but inevitable because they are less academically prepared than the white and Asian students with whom they must compete".<ref>''Fisher v. University of Texas at Austin'', 570 U. S., (Thomas, J., concurring slip op., at 17–18).</ref>
In her dissenting opinion, Justice Ginsburg explained her reasons for affirming the Fifth Circuit's ruling. Noting that the university's 10% plan admitted students regardless of their race, she argued that "the University’s admissions policy flexibly considers race only as a 'factor of a factor of a factor of a factor' ... and is subject to periodic review to ensure that the consideration of race remains necessary and proper to achieve the University's educational objectives ... As I see it, the Court of Appeals has already completed that inquiry, and its judgment, trained on this Court's ''Bakke'' and ''Grutter'' pathmarkers, merits our approbation".<ref>''Fisher v. University of Texas at Austin'', 570 U. S., (Ginsburg, J., dissenting slip op., at 3–4).</ref>
== Back to the Fifth Circuit == In June 2013, the Supreme Court ruled the Fifth Circuit had failed to apply [[strict scrutiny]] to the university's race-conscious admissions policy and sent the case back to the Fifth Circuit court. In November, the Fifth Circuit court heard oral arguments from both sides. In their questions during the arguments, Judges [[Patrick Higginbotham]], [[Carolyn Dineen King]], and [[Emilio M. Garza]] focused on the way the university defines "critical mass" as well as past attempts the university has made to increase minority enrollment.<ref>{{cite news |last= Voeller |first =Amanda| title= Fifth Circuit hears oral arguments for Fisher v. UT case| url= http://www.dailytexanonline.com/news/2013/11/13/fifth-circuit-hears-oral-arguments-for-fisher-v-ut-case| work =The Daily Texan |date =November 14, 2013}}</ref>
On July 15, 2014, the Fifth Circuit announced its decision in favor of UT Austin, with Judge Garza dissenting. In its decision, the majority wrote, “It is equally settled that universities may use race as part of a holistic admissions program where it cannot otherwise achieve diversity.”<ref>[http://www.ca5.uscourts.gov/opinions/pub/09/09-50822-CV2.pdf ''09-50822 5th Circuit Court of Appeals'', (2014).]</ref> Fisher sought a rehearing [[en banc]] with the Fifth Circuit which was denied on 12 of November in a 10–5 decision.<ref>[http://www.ca5.uscourts.gov/opinions/pub/09/09-50822-CV3.pdf ''09-50822 ON PETITION FOR REHEARING EN BANC 5th Circuit Court of Appeals'', (2014).]</ref> Fisher then filed a petition for certiorari to the Supreme Court.<ref>[http://www.scotusblog.com/2015/02/fisher-ii-reaches-the-court/ “Fisher II” reaches the Court]. Scotusblog.com ''February 11th.</ref>
==Return to the Supreme Court== {{Main|Fisher v. University of Texas (2016)}} On June 29, 2015, the Supreme Court announced that they would hear another challenge to UT Austin's admissions policy. The case was assigned docket number 14-981 and oral arguments were heard on December 9.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Sherman|first1=Mark|title=Supreme Court Will Re-Hear Texas Affirmative Action|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/wireStory/supreme-court-hear-texas-affirmative-action-32099271|work=ABC News|agency=AP|date=June 29, 2015}}</ref> Legal analysts predict from the justices' questions that the Court would likely either remand the case again to the lower courts for additional fact-finding, strike down UT Austin's policy, or strike down affirmative action in college admissions nationwide.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Denniston|first1=Lyle|title=Argument analysis: Now, three options on college affirmative action|url=http://www.scotusblog.com/2015/12/argument-analysis-now-three-options-on-college-affirmative-action|work=SCOTUS Blog|date=December 9, 2015}}</ref>
During oral arguments, Justice Scalia raised the [[Affirmative action#Mismatching|mismatching]] theory and questioned whether black students admitted to top-tier schools suffer because the courses are too difficult. Scalia commented that "There are those who contend that it does not benefit African Americans to get them into the University of Texas, where they do not do well, as opposed to having them go to a less-advanced school, a slower-track school where they do well. One of the briefs pointed out that most of the black scientists in this country don't come from schools like the University of Texas. They come from lesser schools where they do not feel that they're being pushed ahead in classes that are too fast for them."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Mencimer|first1=Stephanie|title=Justice Scalia Suggests Blacks Belong at "Slower" Colleges|url=https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2015/12/justice-scalia-suggests-blacks-belong-slower-colleges-fisher-university-texas|work=Mother Jones|date=December 9, 2015}}</ref> The comments led to outcry from the University of Texas's African American students,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hennessy-Fiske|first1=Molly|title=For black students at Texas, Supreme Court remarks are a burden added|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/education/la-na-black-ut-students-20151213-story.html|work=Los Angeles Times|date=December 12, 2015}}</ref> and spurred the creation of the Twitter hashtag #StayMadAbby.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bernstein|first1=Roberta|title=U. of Texas Supreme Court fight gets hashtag: #StayMadAbby|url=http://college.usatoday.com/2015/12/13/u-of-texas-supreme-court-fight-gets-hashtag-staymadabby/|work=USA Today College|date=December 13, 2015}}</ref> As Justice Antonin Scalia died on February 13, 2016 and Justice Elena Kagan recused herself, the case was decided by the seven remaining justices. On June 23, 2016, a 4-3 vote affirmed the Fifth Circuit's decision for UT Austin.

{{More citations needed|date=March 2016}}{{Infobox university |name = François Rabelais University |native_name = Université de TOURS |latin_name = |image = Battanneurs.JPG |image_size = 280px |motto = |established = 1969 |type = Public |endowment = |staff = 1,300 |faculty = |president = Philippe Vendrix |provost = |principal = |rector = |chancellor = |vice_chancellor = |dean = |head_label = |head = |students = 21,207 |undergrad = |postgrad = |doctoral = |profess = |city = [[Tours]] |state = |country = [[France]] |campus = |free_label = |free = |colours = |mascot = |fightsong = |nickname = |affiliations = |footnotes = |website = http://www.univ-tours.fr |address = |telephone = |coor = |logo = }}
'''François Rabelais University''' (French: ''Université François-Rabelais'') or '''University of Tours''' (''Université de Tours''), is a public university in [[Tours]], [[France]]. The university is named after the French writer [[François Rabelais]], and was founded in 1969. As of July 2015 it is a member of the regional university association [[Leonardo da Vinci consolidated University]].<ref name="decret2015">{{cite web|url=http://legifrance.gouv.fr/affichTexte.do?cidTexte=JORFTEXT000030890104&dateTexte=&categorieLien=id|access-date=27 July 2015|title=Decree 2015-857 of 13 July 2015 on the statutes for the ComUE " Université confédérale Léonard de Vinci "}}</ref>
==History== The University of Tours was established as part of efforts to modernize and democratize higher education in France after the [[May 1968 events in France|events of 1968]]. The university was created by grouping together a number of older educational institutions.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.univ-tours.fr/l-universite/quelques-reperes-historiques-89373.kjsp?STNAV=&RUBNAV=&RH=1227187094781 |title=Archived copy |access-date=2017-05-30 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140224180318/http://www.univ-tours.fr/l-universite/quelques-reperes-historiques-89373.kjsp?STNAV=&RUBNAV=&RH=1227187094781 |archive-date=2014-02-24 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
==Organisation== The university has seven campuses, distributed across the city of Tours: * Tanneurs * Tonnellé * Portalis/Deux-Lions * Grandmont * Pont-Volant * Fromont * Emile Zola
==Academics== [[image:Polytech Tours Portalis.jpg|thumb|The Portalis Campus.]] The university comprises seven departments, as well as an engineering school and two technology institutes:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.univ-tours.fr/l-universite/organisation-89397.kjsp?RH=1178118882925&RF=1227187482017|title=Notre fonctionnement|publisher=}}</ref> * Department of Arts and Humanities * Center for Advanced Renaissance Studies (''Centre d'Etudes Supérieures de la Renaissance'') * Department of Law, Economics and Social Sciences * Department of Literature and Languages * Department of Medicine * Department of Sciences and Technology * Department of Pharmacy * School of Engineering (''Ecole Polytechnique de l'université de Tours'') * Tours University Institute of Technology (''Institut Universitaire de Technologie de Tours'') * Blois University Institute of Technology (''Institut Universitaire de Technologie de Blois'')
The university offers bachelor, master and doctorate degrees in line with the [[Bologna Process]]. It also provides Technological Diploma courses (''diplômes universitaire de technologie'') through the two University Institutes of Technology.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://iut-blois.univ-tours.fr/formations/|title=Des formations reconnues par les professionnels|first=Jean-Luc|last=Duriaud|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://iut.univ-tours.fr/formations/les-formations-de-l-iut-384270.kjsp|title=Les formations de l'IUT|first=Florence|last=Dambrine|publisher=}}</ref> Several other institutions operate within the framework of the university: * ''École publique de journalisme de Tours'', a semi-autonomous journalism school affiliated to the university.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://epjt.fr/tout-sur-epjt/ecole-journalisme-reconnue/|title=L’EPJT - EPJT|website=epjt.fr}}</ref> * ''Centre hospitalier régional et universitaire de Tours (CHU de Tours)'', a grouping of six regional hospitals affiliated to the university that collaborate on health services and medical training.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chu-tours.fr/organisation-du-chu/|title=Centre Hospitalier Régional Universitaire de Tours - Organisation du CHU de Tours|first=CHU de Tours / Ackwa.fr / Sébastien|last=Bernard|website=www.chu-tours.fr}}</ref> * ''Institut européen d'histoire et des cultures de l'alimentation'', a humanities and social sciences research center that studies the history of food cultures.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://iehca.eu/fr/qui-sommes-nous|title=Qui sommes-nous ? - IEHCA|website=iehca.eu}}</ref>
==Research== [[image:batLgrandmont.jpg|thumb|Grandmont Campus (Sciences) - Building L]]
Research at the University is at the forefront in the social sciences and humanities in the study of the Renaissance through the Graduate Center of the Renaissance since 1956 and in knowledge of food heritage through a program ambitious research at the Institute of European history and culture of food.
The University of Tours is also distinguished in the field of materials for energy technology research with the Microelectronic at CERTEM in collaboration with ST Microelectronics in 1996.
The research also extends into the field of medical imaging and bio-medicine, oncology, and eminently in the study of autism at the University Hospital of Tours. Geo-science and environment with the study of insects at the Institute for Research on the biology of the insect (IRBI). Since 1969 the CESA, Planning Department today Polytech'Tours research in the field of cities, territories and societies is deemed to France. Finally the University of Tours works in the field of mathematical research through the Laboratory of Theoretical Physics and Mathematics.
==Rankings== In 2016, the [[College and university rankings|Center for World University Rankings]] placed François Rabelais University 682nd in the world and 30th in France.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cwur.org/2016/University-Francois-Rabelais,-Tours.php|title=University François Rabelais, Tours Ranking - CWUR 2016|website=cwur.org}}</ref>
'''Law'''
François Rabelais University undergraduate law program is ranked 3rd in France by [[Eduniversal]], with 3 stars (2016/17).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.meilleures-licences.com/licence-droit.html|title=Classement Licence Droit, top 10 2017-2018 licence Droit|website=www.meilleures-licences.com}}</ref>
==Alumni== Well-known alumni of the university include [[France 3]] journalist [[Marie-Laure Augry]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://assises.journalisme.epjt.fr/marie-laure-augry-la-passion-du-partage|title=[PORTRAIT] Marie-Laure Augry, la passion du partage - Assises.journalisme.epjt.fr|website=assises.journalisme.epjt.fr}}</ref> [[TF1]] journalist [[Harry Roselmack]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.letudiant.fr/metiers/metiers---portraits-de-pros/harry-roselmack-mes-20-ans-15503.html|title=Harry Roselmack ' A 20 ans, j'ai décroché mon DUT de journalisme à l’IUT de Tours'|publisher=}}</ref> and member of the [[National Assembly (France)|National Assembly]] [[Philippe Briand]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.citya.com/societe/parcours-philippe-briand|title=Citya : Administration de biens - Le parcours de Philippe Briand - Citya Immobilier|website=www.citya.com}}</ref>

[[File:ZaryankoSK PtIordona.jpg|thumb|215px|Fyodor Iordan by
[[Sergey Zaryanko]] (1855)]] '''Fyodor Ivanovich Iordan''', or '''Jordan''' (Russian: Фёдор Иванович Иордан; 13 August 1800, [[Pavlovsk, Saint Petersburg|Pavlovsk]] - 19 September 1883, [[Saint Petersburg]]) was a Russian engraver and art professor. He was best known for portraits and reproductions of the [[Old Masters]]. == Biography == His father was the upholsterer for the Imperial Court.[https://ru.wikisource.org/wiki/%D0%AD%D0%A1%D0%91%D0%95/%D0%98%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B4%D0%B0%D0%BD,_%D0%A4%D0%B5%D0%B4%D0%BE%D1%80_%D0%98%D0%B2%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B8%D1%87 Brief biography] from the ''[[Brockhaus and Efron Encyclopedic Dictionary]]'' @ Russian WikiSource. He was enrolled in the primary school courses at the [[Imperial Academy of Arts]] and, in 1819, entered the engraving class, serving as an apprentice of [[Nikolai Utkin]].[http://petroart.ru/en/art/i/iordan/main.php Brief biography] @ PetroArt. He graduated in 1824 and received a gold medal for his engraving, "Mercury lulls Argus", after a painting by [[Pyotr Sokolov (portraitist)|Pyotr Sokolov]]. Shortly after, he was awarded another gold medal at one of the Academy's exhibitions for his rendering of the "Dying Abel", after a work by [[Anton Losenko]]. In 1829, he went to Paris, where he studied with [[Théodore Richomme]]. When the [[July Revolution]] began, he moved to London, continuing his studies with [[Abraham Raimbach]] and [[John Henry Robinson]]. In 1834, he settled in Rome where, at the urging of [[Karl Briullov]], he produced a huge engraving of the "[[Transfiguration (Raphael)|Transfiguration" by Raphael]], which took him twelve (some sources say fifteen) years to complete. As a result of this work, he became an honorary member of the [[Academy of Arts, Berlin]] and the [[Accademia delle Arti del Disegno]] in Florence. He was named an Academician by the Imperial Academy in 1844 and was awarded the title of Professor in 1850, when he returned to Saint Petersburg. After the death of {{ill|Stepan Galaktionov|ru|Галактионов, Степан Филиппович}} in 1854, he became head of the engraving department at the Academy and was appointed an assistant curator for prints and drawings at the [[Hermitage Museum|Hermitage]]. The following year, he married Varvara Pushchin (1833-1916), a close relative of the poet, [[Pyotr Pletnyov]]. In 1861, he gave private engraving lessons to [[Taras Shevchenko]].Taras Shevchenko. Works: "Dnepr", 1971, Vol. V, p. 176-177. He was promoted to head curator of prints after the death of Nikolai Utkin in 1863. Eight years later, he became a Rector in the painting and sculpture departments (the only time this position has been held by an engraver) and, in 1876, was named a superintendent in the mosaic division. Towards the end of his life, he was appointed [[Privy Councilor]]. ==Selected portraits==
File:Iordan-Pavlovich.jpg|[[Grand Duke Michael Pavlovich]] File:Гравюра Ф. І. Йордана. Д. О. Ровинський.png|[[Dmitry Rovinsky]] File:Гравюра Ф. І. Йордана. В. А. Каратигін.png|[[Vasily Karatygin]] File:Гравюра Ф. І. Йордана. Істоміна А. І..png|[[Avdotia Istomina]]
==References== {{reflist}} == Further reading == * Nikolai Belyaev (compiler), ''Записки ректора и профессора Академии художеств Федора Ивановича Иордана'' (Notes of a Rector and Professor at the Academy of Arts), Библиотека Российской Академии Наук, 2012 {{ISBN|5-336-00141-4}} * [https://ru.wikisource.org/wiki/%D0%A0%D0%91%D0%A1/%D0%92%D0%A2/%D0%98%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B4%D0%B0%D0%BD,_%D0%A4%D0%B5%D0%B4%D0%BE%D1%80_%D0%98%D0%B2%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B8%D1%87 Biography and appreciation] from the ''[[Russian Biographical Dictionary]]'' @ Russian WikiSource. ==External links== {{commonscat inline|Fyodor Iordan}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Iordan, Fyodor}} [[Category:1800 births]] [[Category:1883 deaths]] [[Category:Russian engravers]] [[Category:People from Pavlovsk, Saint Petersburg]] [[Category:Russian art directors]] [[Category:Curators]]

revision.text:
{{About|musical/choir group|other uses|Glee club (disambiguation)}} [[File:Miami University Men's Glee Club 1907.jpg|thumb|400px|The [[Miami University Glee Club]] in 1907]] A '''glee club''' is a musical group or choir group, historically of male voices but also of female or mixed voices, which traditionally specializes in the singing of short songs—[[Glee (music)|glees]]—by trios or quartets. In the late 19th century it was very popular in most schools and was made a tradition to have in American high schools from then on. The first named Glee Club was founded in [[Harrow School]] in [[London]] in 1787, where an annual Glee competition is still held.<ref name="firstgleeclub">{{cite journal |url=https://books.google.com/?id=bbYPAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA324&dq=history+of+%22glee+clubs%22 |last=Bacon |first=Richard Mackenzie |authorlink=Richard Mackenzie Bacon |title=The Catch and Glee Clubs |journal=The Quarterly musical magazine and review |volume=II |issue=VII |pages=328ff |location=London |year=1820 }}</ref> Glee clubs were very popular in Britain from then until the mid-1850s but by then they were gradually being superseded by choral societies. ''Glee'' in this context does not refer to the mood of the music or of its singers, but to a specific form of English part song popular between 1650 and 1900, the [[Glee (music)|glee]]. But by the mid-20th century, proper ''glee'' clubs were no longer common.
The term remains in contemporary use, however, for [[choir]]s established in [[North America]]n [[college]]s, [[university|universities]], and high schools, although most American glee clubs are choruses in the standard sense, and rarely perform ''glees''.
==Oldest United States collegiate glee clubs== The oldest [[List of collegiate glee clubs|collegiate glee clubs in the United States]] are, by year of foundation: * 1858: [[Harvard Glee Club]]<ref>{{cite web |title=History of the Harvard Glee Club |url=http://www.harvardgleeclub.org/info/history/ |accessdate=2009-10-15 }}</ref> * 1859: [[University of Michigan Men's Glee Club]] * 1861: [[Yale Glee Club]] * 1862: [[Wesleyan University|Wesleyan University Glee Club]]<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.wesleyan.edu/communications/images/magazine_assets/10-2_musicalcampus.pdf |accessdate = 2014-09-29 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140506102246/http://www.wesleyan.edu/communications/images/magazine_assets/10-2_musicalcampus.pdf |archivedate = 2014-05-06 |df = }} </ref> * 1862: [[The University of Pennsylvania Glee Club]]<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.archives.upenn.edu/histy/genlhistory/timeline.html | title = The University of Pennsylvania Archives}} </ref> * 1865: [[Amherst College Glee Club]]<ref>{{cite web |url = https://www.amherst.edu/academiclife/departments/music/performances/glee_club |title = Amherst Glee Club Website |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110628181822/https://www.amherst.edu/academiclife/departments/music/performances/glee_club |archivedate = 2011-06-28 |df = }} </ref> * 1868: [[Cornell University Glee Club]]<ref>{{cite web |title = Glee Club History |url = http://www.gleeclub.com/about/history.php |accessdate = 2009-12-13 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090107054252/http://www.gleeclub.com/about/history.php |archivedate = 2009-01-07 |df = }}</ref> * 1869: [[Union College Men's Glee Club]] * 1869: Lehigh University Glee Club * 1871: [[Virginia Glee Club]]<ref name="uvaiv">{{cite book | last=Bruce | first=Philip Alexander | authorlink=Philip Alexander Bruce | title=History of the University of Virginia, 1818-1919 |volume=IV | publisher=[[Macmillan Publishers (United States)|MacMillan]] | year=1921 | pages=127–128, 841 | url=https://books.google.com/?id=ns0zAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA127&dq=%22cabell+house%22+virginia#PPA127,M1 }}</ref> * 1872: [[Rutgers University Glee Club]]<ref>{{cite web |title = RU Glee Club History |url = http://eden.rutgers.edu/~rugc/history.html |accessdate = 2010-01-21 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100717141631/http://eden.rutgers.edu/~rugc/history.html |archivedate = 2010-07-17 |df = }}</ref> * 1874: [[Princeton Glee Club]] * 1874: Worcester Polytechnic Institute Men's Glee Club * 1875: [[The Ohio State University Men's Glee Club]]<ref> {{cite web * 1893: University of Michigan Women’s Glee Club<ref>{{cite web |title = University of Michigan Women’s Glee Club |url=https://www.umwgc.org |accessdate=2018-02-28 }}</ref> * 1893: [[Purdue Varsity Glee Club]]<ref>{{cite web |title = Purdue Varsity Glee Club History |url = https://www.purdue.edu/pmo/ensembles/purdue-varsity-glee-club/ |accessdate=2017-02-15}}</ref> * 1893: [[Texas A&M Singing Cadets]]<ref>{{cite web |title = The History of the Fightin’ Texas Aggie Singing Cadets |url = https://singingcadets.tamu.edu/history/overview/ |accessdate=2018-11-16}}</ref> *1897: Case Men's Glee Club (Case Institute of Technology and Western Reserve University) *1901: The University of Oklahoma Men's Glee Club * 1906: [[Georgia Tech Glee Club]]<ref> {{cite web |url=http://gleeclub.gatech.edu/index.php?p=about |title=About the Georgia Tech Glee Club |accessdate= 2016-02-27 }} </ref> * 1907: [[Wheaton College Men's Glee Club]],<ref>{{cite web |title=Wheaton College Men's Glee Club |url=http://www.wheaton.edu/Academics/Departments/Conservatory/Ensembles/Mens-Glee-Club |accessdate=2016-11-14 }}</ref> [[Miami University Glee Club]] * 1911: [[Morehouse College Glee Club]]<ref> {{cite web |url=http://mcgclub.com/ |title=The Official Morehouse Glee Club Website |accessdate=2015-09-19 }}</ref>
The oldest non-collegiate glee club in the United States is the [[Mendelssohn Glee Club]], founded in 1866.<ref name="mgc-papers">{{cite web |url=http://www.nypl.org/sites/default/files/archivalcollections/pdf/musmende.pdf |title=Mendelssohn Club Papers |author=New York Library for the Performing Arts |format=[[PDF]] |accessdate=2011-02-25}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Use British English|date=August 2014}} The '''Guildhall Lectures''' were an annual series of talks on the theme of communication, organised by the [[British Association]].
The lectures, held in the [[London Guildhall]], were sponsored and broadcast by [[Granada Television]]. The first set of three lectures were held in 1959,<ref>Asa Briggs, ''The History of Broadcasting in the United Kingdom, Vol. 5'', p.457</ref> and they continued until at least 1984. Broadly on the theme of "Communication in the Modern World", they concerned the [[arts]], [[science]]s, [[politics]] and [[mass media]].<ref>Charles Curran et al, ''Television Today and Tomorrow'', p.5</ref>
==List of lectures== {| class="wikitable" !Year !Theme !Speakers |- |1959 |Communication in the Modern World |[[Edward Victor Appleton|Edward Appleton]], [[Eric Ashby]], [[Edward Murrow]] |- |1960 |Communication in the Modern World |[[Edgar Adrian, 1st Baron Adrian|Edgar Adrian]], [[George Wells Beadle|George W. Beadle]], [[Hans Eysenck]] |- |1961 |Communication in the Modern World |[[Hermann Bondi]], [[James Gray (zoologist)|James Gray]], [[John Wolfenden]] |- |1962 |Communication in the Modern World |[[John Kenneth Galbraith]], [[Yoshinori Maeda]], [[Yigael Yadin]] |- |1963 |Communication in the Modern World |[[A. J. Ayer]], [[Patrick Blackett, Baron Blackett|Patrick Blackett]], J. Zacharias |- |1964 |Communication in the Modern World |[[William Holford]], [[George Armitage Miller|George Miller]], [[Stein Rokkan]] |- |1965 |Communication in the Modern World |[[Alistair Cooke]], [[J. B. Rhine]], [[Hyman G. Rickover]] |- |1966 |Telecommunications: The Next Ten Years |[[Kenneth Clark]], [[Sebastian De Ferranti]], [[Francis McLean (engineer)|Francis McLean]] |- |1967 |Only Connect |[[Asa Briggs]], [[Hugh Cudlipp]], [[Fred Friendly]] |- |1968 |Communication in the Modern World |[[Lawrence Alloway]], Paul Chambers, [[Richard Crossman]] |- |1969 |Universities: Boundaries of Change |[[Paul M. Doty|Paul Doty]], [[Jack Straw]], [[Albert Sloman]] |- |1970 | | |- |1971 | | |- |1972 |The Future of Broadcasting in Britain |[[Hugh Greene]] |- |1973 | | |- |1974 |The Freedom of the Press |[[Harold Evans]], [[Katharine Graham]], [[David Hennessy, 3rd Baron Windlesham|David Windlesham]] |- |1975 |Government, Broadcasting and the Press |[[Roy Jenkins]] |- |1976 | | |- |1977 |Television Today and Tomorrow |[[Noel Annan, Baron Annan|Noel Annan]], [[Charles Curran (broadcaster)|Charles Curran]], Brian Young |- |1978 | | |- |1979 | | |- |1980 |The Role of the Trade Unions |[[Tony Benn]], [[Len Murray]], [[James Prior, Baron Prior|Jim Prior]] |- |1981 | | |- |1982 |The Liberty of the Citizen |[[John Hunt, Baron Hunt|John Hunt]], [[John Mortimer]], [[Franklin A. Thomas]] |- |1983 | | |- |1984 |The Right to Know |[[Floyd Abrams]], [[Michael Kirby (judge)|Michael Kirby]], [[Leslie Scarman, Baron Scarman|Leslie Scarman]] |- |1985 | | |- |1986 | | |- |1987 |Will Cabinet Government Survive? |[[Quintin Hogg, Baron Hailsham of St Marylebone|Quintin Hogg]] |- |1988 | | |- |1989 |Europe: Our Sort of Community |[[Leon Brittan]] |}
==References== <references />

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=May 2014}} {{Infobox publisher | name = Hooked on Phonics | image = | caption = | parent = Sandviks | status = | traded_as = | predecessor = | founded = 1987 | founder = <!-- or | founders = --> | successor = | country = United States | headquarters = [[Danbury, Connecticut]] | distribution = [[Simon & Schuster]]<ref>[http://www.simonandschusterpublishing.com/sns-distribution/our-clients.html Our Valued Clients]</ref> | keypeople = | publications = Books | topics = | genre = | imprints = | revenue = | owner = | numemployees = | url = {{URL|https://www.hookedonphonics.com}} }}
'''Hooked on Phonics''' is a commercial brand of educational materials, originally designed for [[reading education]] through [[phonetics]]. First marketed in 1987, it used systematic phonics and scaffolded stories to teach letter–sound correlations (phonics) as part of children's literacy. The program has since expanded to encompass a wide variety of media, including books, [[computer game]]s, music, videos, and [[Flashcards|flash card]]s in addition to books in its materials, as well as to include other subject areas. The target audience for this brand is primarily individuals and home school parents. The product was advertised extensively on television and radio throughout the 1990s.
==History== {{refimprove|section|date=May 2014}} Hooked on Phonics was developed in the 1980s by a father who wanted to help his son overcome his reading problems. The original Hooked on Phonics ''Learn to Read'' product was released by Gateway Educational Products in 1987.
The company built a successful business based upon significant advertising, leading to sales of over $100M per year. The product, along with its [[catchphrase]] "Hooked on Phonics worked for me!" (spoken by children in the product's [[television commercial|television ads]]) and its telephone number "1-800-ABCDEFG" (now belonging to the Wilshire Law Firm), became widely recognized during the mid-1990s.
In 1994 the company was featured on the program ''[[Dateline NBC]]'' with an official from the [[Federal Trade Commission|FTC]] attacking the company for "deceptive advertising". The FTC and Gateway reached a settlement later, with Gateway agreeing to advertising ground rules and disclosure of all research data and consumer complaints.<ref>{{cite news |author=Aaron Nathans |title=Hooked on Phonics Settles With FTC on Advertising Claims | date=1994-12-15 |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1994-12-15/news/mn-9369_1_hooked-on-phonics-program |newspaper=Los Angeles Times}}</ref> Nevertheless, the negative media coverage caused the company's sales to plummet and for the company to file for bankruptcy protection.
The year 2001 saw the introduction of test-taking strategies and [[study skills]] as part of the "Hooked on School Success" program and a new partnership with [[KinderCare Learning Centers]] to use materials in KinderCare's private [[child care]] facilities.
In 2004 the FTC fined the company, then called Gateway Learning Corporation, for retroactively changing their privacy policy without informing customers, and subsequently sharing private information about customers including children with outside marketing firms.<ref>{{cite news |author=Bob Sullivan |title=Hooked on Phonics fined by FTC |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/5386195/ns/technology_and_science-security/t/hooked-phonics-fined-ftc/ |date=2004-07-07 |publisher=NBCNews.com}}</ref>
In 2005 the product line was acquired by Educate, Inc., who also operated [[Sylvan Learning]], and began selling products in retail. In 2006 the company released a new line of educational programs including ''Hooked on Spanish'', ''Hooked on Handwriting'', and ''Hooked on Spelling'', among many others.
By 2007, the Hooked on Phonics program had been introduced in over 30 countries.
Hooked on Phonics was taken private in 2007 and the company renamed to Smarterville, Inc.
The flagship ''Learn to Read'' product underwent a major redesign, featuring DVDs, web customizations, and an entire new line of systematic phonics readers. It was launched in the summer of 2009. Sixty music videos were added, composed by [[Russell Ginns]] and featuring performances by [[Cathy Fink]], [[Marcy Marxer]] and the a cappella group [[The Bobs]].
Hooked on Phonics was acquired by Sandviks Inc., in 2011.
Their Hooked on Phonics mobile app for iOS and Android was launched in 2013. As of 2018, it has been download more and 500,000 times.
==Awards== {{unreferenced|section|date=May 2014}} Hooked on Phonics' products have won several awards over the years, including: * National Parenting Seal of Approval in 1998, 2005 and 2007 * Teachers' Choice Award in 2004, 2008 and 2009 * Curriculum Administrator Districts’ Choice in 2001
==See also== * [[List of Phonics Programs]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.hookedonphonics.com/ Hooked on Phonics website]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Hooked On Phonics}} [[Category:Phonics curricula]] [[Category:Products introduced in 1987]] [[Category:Learning to read]] [[Category:Phonetics]]

{{no footnotes|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox <!-- Commented out because image was deleted: |image=SMSinspired.jpg --> |name=Inspired |caption=Inspired Logo |data1=Science Museum Swindon |data2='Wroughton' }}
'''''Inspired''''' is an ambitious new [[project]] being developed by the [[Science Museum (London)|Science Museum]] in [[London]], [[England]]. The Science Museum holds some of the greatest [[Collection (museum)|collections]] of their kind in the world. However, it is currently only able to display around 8% of its objects, while the rest are hidden away from the public in deep storage at the [[Science Museum Swindon]] and [[Blythe House]]. ''Inspired'' aims to bring all of these objects together in an extensive, [[sustainable]] new facility at the [[Science Museum Swindon]] and open them up to the public, accompanied by comprehensive public engagement in science and engineering, learning programmes and outdoor events.
==External links== * [http://www.sciencemuseumswindon.org.uk/ ''Inspired'' at the Science Museum Swindon] * [http://www.sciencemuseum.org.uk/ Science Museum website] * [http://www.nmsi.ac.uk/ National Museum of Science and Industry website]
[[Category:Educational projects]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2018}} {{unreferenced|date=December 2014}} The '''Inter-University Council for East Africa''' (IUCEA), based in [[Kampala]], [[Uganda]], is an institution of the inter-governmental organisation, the [[East African Community]]. IUCEA aims to foster collaboration between universities in [[Kenya]], [[Tanzania]], [[Uganda]], [[Burundi]], [[Rwanda]] and [[South Sudan]].
'''Historical Background'''
In East Africa regional higher education interactions and cooperation originates from the pre-independence era when Makerere University College was the only higher education institution in the region serving students from Kenya, the then Tanganyika, and Zanzibar in East Africa
as well as from the then Rhodesia and Nyasaland in central and southern Africa, which now consist of Malawi, Zambia and Zimbabwe. Later in 1963, university colleges were formed in Nairobi and Dar es Salaam as constituent colleges of the then University of East Africa that had been established during the era of independence of the four countries (Uganda, Kenya, Zanzibar and Tanganyika). Makerere College was the third constituent college of the University of East Africa.
In 1970, the University of East Africa was dissolved and the University of Dar es Salaam, Makerere University and the University of Nairobi were established as separate national universities for Tanzania, Uganda and Kenya respectively. In the same year, due to the need to maintain collaboration between these universities the Inter-University Committee (IUC) was established under the auspices of the first EAC. The role of IUC was to facilitate contact and cooperation among the three universities (University of Dar es Salaam, Makerere University and University of Nairobi). IUC was hosted in Kampala, Uganda. In 1977, the former EAC collapsed and the support that IUC was receiving from the Partner States declined. However, IUC continued to coordinate cooperation between the three universities albeit with resource constraints that severely limited its functions.
'''Establishment of IUCEA'''
In 1980, after consultations involving permanent/principal secretaries responsible for higher education in Uganda, Tanzania and Kenya, the vice chancellors of the universities in the three countries met in Nairobi (Kenya) to discuss the future of the cooperation of their institutions. They agreed to sign a memorandum of understanding (MoU) committing them to maintain cooperation between their universities within the IUC framework. The MoU was subsequently signed, which also led to the transformation of IUC into the current Inter-university Council for East Africa (IUCEA). The MoU spelt out the objectives, functions, membership and governance of IUCEA, and, just like IUC, IUCEA continued and still is hosted in Kampala, Uganda. IUCEA played its role very well until 1992 when decline in financial support from the three governments of Kenya, Tanzania and Uganda made it impossible to carry out the collaborative activities. This raised concern about institutional sustainability and hence prompted a study by the Commonwealth Higher Education Management Services (CHEMS) between November 1998 and March 1999 with a view to revitalizing IUCEA. The aim of the study was to develop a viable strategy for expansion and sustainability of IUCEA.
'''Revitalized IUCEA and Integration into EAC Framework'''
The Treaty for the Establishment of the current East African Community (The Treaty) was signed on 30 November 1999 and entered into force on 7 July 2000 following its ratification by the original three Partner States, namely Republic of Kenya, Republic of Uganda, and United Republic of Tanzania. The Republic of Burundi and the Republic of Rwanda acceded to the EAC Treaty on 18 June 2007 and became full Members of the Community with effect from 1 July 2007. Upon its re-establishment, EAC recognized IUCEA as one of the surviving institutions of the former Community. Therefore, it was agreed to establish IUCEA as an institution of the new EAC. In that process in 2000 IUCEA underwent revitalization following the recommendations of the CHEMS study and in 2002 the Ministers responsible for Higher Education of Kenya, Tanzania and Uganda signed the IUCEA Protocol as an instrument that made IUCEA a legal body corporate of EAC.
'''The IUCEA Act, 2009'''
In 2009 the East African Legislative Assembly (EALA) enacted the IUCEA Act 2009, thus effectively integrating IUCEA into the EAC operational framework. The Act spells out the objectives, functions, institutional set up and systems of governance and management of IUCEA. According to the Act any university, university college and degree awarding institution may apply for and get admitted to the IUCEA membership as long as it is properly incorporated in the EAC Partner State where it is operating and is pursuing objectives that are consistent with the functions of IUCEA as spelt out in the Act.
==External links== * [http://www.iucea.org IUCEA website]
{{Uganda-stub}}Since 1970, Kenya was founding members of IUCEA{{Kenya-stub}}Since 1970, Kenya was founding members of IUCEA{{Tanzania-stub}}Since 1970, Kenya was founding members of IUCEA{{Rwanda-stub}} {{Burundi-stub}} {{South Sudan-stub}}
