{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} [[File:Orgelkids Doe-orgel leskist.jpg|thumb|200px|The Do-organ of Orgelkids]] '''Orgelkids''' (Dutch, "organkids") is an [[education]]al project meant to familiarize and educate children with the [[pipe organ]] musical instrument. The project was initiated in the [[Netherlands]] in 2009 by Lydia Vroegindeweij and is directed towards [[cultural heritage|cultural legacy]] and [[music education]]. Initially the project consisted of a website with educational tips and lesson suggestions to organize, among other projects, an excursion to a large pipe organ. Since 2013, Orgelkids has at its disposal a speciallly developed educational organ assembly kit. A complete, craftsman-built organ, in unassembled component parts, is contained in a lesson box. The instrument can be assembled and subsequently played. This so-called Do-organ is rented out by Orgelkids to [[organist]]s, [[organ builder]]s or organ teachers who want to organize educational projects for children. == Justification / Background == The classical pipe organ is almost always built in a fixed location in a building and not very accessible for children. Due to increased [[secularization]] of society, fewer children attend churches, so they have fewer occasions to spontaneously experience a pipe organ.an. 2016. Many smaller churches in N. America have electronic organs.
In the Netherlands there is a wealth of historical organs. For the preservation and maintenance of this cultural legacy, it is important to encourage a continuing flow of new organists and organ builders. To prevent that knowledge and enthusiasm for organs continue to decline, Orgelkids has made a special instrument available to schools. An [[organist]] or [[organ builder]] visits the school with the Do-organ and supervises the students as they build/assemble the organ. == Orgelkids Do-organ == [[File:2013 Orgelkids Doe-orgel pijpen plaatsen.jpg|thumb|180px|left|Children in primary school are assembling the Do-organ]] An organ in a lesson box is a unique concept, first conceived and built by Dutch organ builder Wim Janssen specially for the goal of educating children with the technology and playing of the organ. It is not a demonstration organ with just a few keys, but a real instrument with which children can self-discover how it works. That is the reason it was given the name, "Do-organ." The Orgelkids instrument is a mechanical, tracker organ with two [[octave]]s (24 keys) and two [[organ stop|registers]] which can be used independently or in combination. Air (wind in organ parlance) is supplied by a hand-pumped [[bellows]].Verhoeven 2016. All the materials used are identical to those used in a large pipe organ (such as [[oak wood]] and [[sheepskin|sheep leather]]). Children experience the value and quality of craftsman-made instruments. The lesson box is supplied with instruction manuals which include many photos, by which children can assemble the organ with a minimum of instructions, in about 45 minutes. In addition, there are other lesson materials available such as an [[instructional video]] by the builder, an [[e-book]], and a presentation for a digital [[blackboard]]. Ton Stevens, organist of the basilica of St. John in [[Oosterhout]], the Netherlands, works with kids on [[World Animal Day]] in the basilica every year. First they build and play the Do-organ of Orgelkids, and afterwards the children can take a look at the "real" organ built by [[Maarschalkerweerd]] in 1890. Of course songs like ''[[Old MacDonald Had a Farm]]'' are played on the organ on the occasion of that special day.Rodenburg 2014 == International developments == Orgelkids started in the [[Netherlands]] in 2013 with a single lesson box. The home for this organ is in the [[Amersfoort]] region, which is in the center of the country. In the first year, 1350 children were reached. In 2015 it was expanded with a second organ which is based in [[Belgium]], operating out of [[Antwerp]]. In its first year there, 800 children were reached. The project has attracted more international attention. In Oregon a sister project, Orgelkids USA, an educational 501c3 nonprofit,{{cite web|title=Orgelkids USA|url=http://www.orgelkidsusa.org|website=orgelkidsusa.org|accessdate=28 October 2016}} was launched in 2016 with the mission to help grow a nationwide network of independent kits. They helped place five organ kits built by the US builders in their first year. Orgelkids USA kits are being commissioned to serve as regional resources by chapters of the [[American Guild of Organists]] as well as by non-profit organizations whose missions are pipe organ related. == Training for organ builders == Since 2016, Orgelkids has been supporting the training of organ builders and the passing down of artisanal skills. Organ building shops can have apprentice builders work on an Orgelkids instrument during their practical training. In doing so they develop all manner of practical skills which are also needed in the building or restoration of large, monumental organs. After completion, the organ kit can be made available for educational projects. For those who wish to build an organ kit themselves, building instructions are available including 20 technical drawings that correspond to the original organ. == Foundation == The Orgelkids project has been brought into the Dutch "Stichting Kerk Muziek Netwerk" (Church Music Network Foundation) since 2013.Van den Broucke en Vroegindeweij 2016, p. 113. This non-profit foundation engages to make relevant aspects of church music accessible to the greater public. == Orgelkids USA == US-based Orgelkids USA was founded in June 2015 as a program{{cite web|title=OrgelKids - USA, Pipe Speak, 1st November 2015, Volume 6 No. 3|url=http://agoeugene.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/Nov-2015-Newsletter-Final.pdf|website=Eugene American Guild of Organists|accessdate=28 October 2016}} of the Eugene Oregon USA chapter of the American Guild of Organists,{{cite web|title=Eugene AGO|url=http://agoeugene.org/|website=Eugene American Guild of Organists|accessdate=28 October 2016}} and later incorporated on 29 August 2016 as a section-501(c)(3) non-profit organization. Orgelkids USA shares a similar educational and outreach agenda as the original Netherlands-based Orgelkids organization, serving as a pilot program for the US and helping grow a nationwide network of independent organ kits. Orgelkids USA was launched with a generous grant by the New York City American Guild of Organists (AGO) '{{cite web|title=NYC AGO|url=http://www.nycago.org|website=New York City American Guild of Organists|accessdate=28 October 2016}} Centennial Millennium Fund,{{cite web|title=OrgelKids USA Update, Pipe Speak, 1st April 2016, Volume 6 No. 8|url=http://agoeugene.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/April-2016-Newsletter-Final.pdf|website=Eugene American Guild of Organists|accessdate=28 October 2016}}{{cite web|title=Thank You, New York, from the Eugene, Oregon Chapter of the AGO, Newsletter, May 2016, Vol. 66, No. 8|url=http://www.nycago.org/Newsletter/1605newsletter.html|website=New York City American Guild of Organists|accessdate=28 October 2016}} , similar grants from the San Francisco and Seattle chapters of AGO and a social media fundraising campaign.{{cite news|title=Two kids with a goal|url=http://www.gazettetimes.com/news/local/two-kids-with-a-goal/article_a8f05189-dc77-5deb-8cb2-d1cd64783831.html|accessdate=28 October 2016|work=Gazette Times|publisher=Mid-Valley Media Group|date=11 October 2016}} 2017 was an inaugural year of outreach programing in the USA with two Orgelkids USA kits reaching over 700 people.{{Cite web|url=https://www.voxhumanajournal.com/scheessele2018|title=A New Organ Outreach: Orgelkids USA|last=Scheessele|first=Erin|date=June 3, 2018|website=Vox Humana|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-06-05}} == Footnotes == {{Reflist}} == References == * {{Aut|an.}} (2016) - 'Beleving maakt jeugd enthousiast voor orgel of carillon.' (verslag oprichtingssymposium Stichting Klinkend Erfgoed Nederland (SKEN)) in: [[Reformatorisch Dagblad]], 9 September 2016.[http://www.rd.nl/muziek/beleving-maakt-jeugd-enthousiast-voor-orgel-of-carillon-1.1124608 online available] (consulted 2016-10-24). * {{Aut|van den Broucke, Daniel en Lydia Vroegindeweij}} (2016) - 'Orgelkids! Inspire children for pipe organs.' In: Proceedings, Interpret Europe Conference organised by Herita, Mechelen, p. 111- 116; [http://www.interpret-europe.net/fileadmin/news-tmp/ie-events/2016/proceedings_interpret_confpapers.pdf pdf online available] (consulted 2016-10-23). * {{Aut|Karels, Jan-Kees}} (2013) - 'Maak kinderen enthousiast voor het orgel.' In: Reformatorisch Dagblad, 3 juli 2013. [http://www.rd.nl/muziek/maak-kinderen-enthousiast-voor-het-orgel-1.321676 online available] (consulted 2016-10-24). * {{Aut|Duin, Maartje}} (2014) - ‘De gulle gever is vaak alleenstaand’. In: [[de Volkskrant]] 20 November 2014.[http://www.volkskrant.nl/dossier-singleblog/de-gulle-gever-is-vaak-alleenstaand~a3793949/ online available] (consulted 2016-10-23). * {{Aut|Rodenburg, Wijtse}} (2014) - 'Ton Stevens, actief met orgels, concerten en kinderen rond Oosterhout....' In: ''Brabants Orgelrijkdom'' 2014, 7th annual publication of the Brabantse Orgelfederatie. Pag. 14-18. [http://www.brabantorgel.nl/BrabantFederatie_Orgelmagazine2014.html online available as pdf] (retrieved 2016-11-11). * {{Aut|van der Ros, Wim}} (2016) - 'Lydia Vroegindeweij, een vrouw die niet stil kan zitten', in: ''De Orgelvriend'', jaargang 58, nummer 10, oktober 2016, pag. 6-10. * {{Aut|Verhoeven, Anneke}} (2016) - 'Met de klas een pijporgel bouwen.' In: Leusder krant. 3 augustus 2016. [http://leusderkrant.nl/lokaal/met-de-klas-een-pijporgel-bouwen-144499 online available] (consulted 2016-10-23). == External links == * [http://orgelkids.nl/?lang=en www.orgelkids.nl] the Dutch website of Orgelkids (in English) * [http://www.orgelinvlaanderen.be/doe-orgel/ Information about Orgelkids in Flanders] (in Dutch) on the website of de "Vereniging Het orgel in Vlaanderen" (society The Pipe Organ in Flanders). * [http://orgelkidsusa.org/ www.OrgelkidsUSA.org] The website of Orgelkids USA [[Category:Pipe organ]] [[Category:Music education]] [[Category:Music organisations based in the Netherlands]]

{{advert|date=March 2016}} {{Infobox university| image =| name = Pennco Tech| motto = Turning Dreams Into Reality| city = 3815 Otter St, Bristol, Pennsylvania
and
99 Erial Rd, Blackwood, New Jersey| country = United States| established = 1973| students = 400 | faculty = 29 | website = http://www.penncotech.edu| type = [[For-profit college|For-profit]] }} '''Pennco Tech''' is a [[technical school]] with locations in [[Bristol, Pennsylvania]], and [[Blackwood, New Jersey]].[https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/16/nyregion/new-jersey-schools-trail-nation-in-repayment-of-student-loans.html New Jersey Schools Trail Nation In Repayment of Student Loans], ''[[The New York Times]]'', November 16, 1997 It was founded in 1973. ==Academics== Pennco Tech awards certificates and diplomas in healthcare and technology fields. At Pennco Tech, all programs and areas of study have local advisory boards composed of industry business personnel assembled to make sure curriculum encompasses real-world need and experience. ==Areas of study== *'''Air Conditioning, Refrigeration, Heating''' *'''Automotive Body & Paint Technician'''- Pennco Tech's Auto Body and Paint training program teaches the fundamentals of welding, plastics, hand and power tools, body repairs, metalwork and finishing, and glass repair and replacement. *'''Automotive Technology'''- Pennco Tech offers an Automotive Technology training program that teaches students combustion engine basics, computerized engine diagnostics, power trains, electrical systems and circuitry, welding, brakes, and reconditioning. *'''Diesel/Truck Technology'''- Pennco Tech's Diesel/Truck Technology program teaches the automotive technology program basics as well as truck safety inspection and hydraulics. The engine-focused curriculum of the Diesel/Truck Technology course examines and rebuilding techniques and troubleshooting practices for engine blocks, blowers and turbochargers on [[Cummins]], [[Volvo]], Caterpillar, [[Detroit diesel|Detroit]], [[Volvo Penta|Penta]] and [[International Harvester]] engines. *'''[[Electrician]]'''- The electrician training program at Pennco Tech is designed to teach the fundamentals of commercial, residential, and industrial wiring. The curriculum also instructs on telecommunication devices and wiring AV. *'''[[Computer-aided design|Mechanical/CAD Drafting]]''' *'''Medical Assistant – Administrative'''- Pennco Tech offers a Medical Assistant – Administrative training program designed to teach students basic tasks and procedures in medical office settings, from updating patients’ medical records, scheduling appointments, and assisting physicians during patient examinations. *'''[[Pharmacy technician|Pharmacy Technician]]'''- Pennco Tech's Pharmacy Technician training program teaches the fundamentals of pill counting, prescription filling, measuring amounts of medication and labeling products. *'''Plumbing and Heating Technology'''- Pennco Tech's 900-hour Plumbing and Heating Technology program is offered only at their Pennsylvania location. The curriculum is evenly split between refrigeration, heating systems, plumbing, and common technologies among these specializations. ==Accreditation== Pennco Tech is accredited by the [[Accrediting Commission of Career Schools and Colleges of Technology]]. ==Pennco Tech Bristol Campus== Pennco Tech's Bristol, Pennsylvania campus is located at 3815 Otter St, Bristol, PA 19007. The Pennco Tech Bristol campus offers a plumbing and heating curriculum not available at Pennco Tech's Blackwood campus. ==Pennco Tech Blackwood Campus== Pennco Tech's Blackwood, New Jersey campus is located at 99 Erial Rd, Blackwood, NJ 08012. The Pennco Tech Blackwood campus offers Diesel/Truck Technology and Mechanical/CAD Drafting curriculum not available at Pennco Tech's Bristol campus. ==Lawsuit== In 2011, Matthew Hamilton, a former admissions representative at Pennco, claimed that Pennco fired him for refusing to participate in a scheme that ensured every student who applied would be enrolled.{{cite news|last1=Morelli|first1=Lana|title=Admissions Rep Calls School a RICO Scam|url=http://www.courthousenews.com/2011/04/19/35905.htm|accessdate=1 February 2015|publisher=Courthouse News Service|date=April 19, 2011}} == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{official website|http://www.penncotech.edu}} *[http://www.papsa.org/pent.html Pennco Tech listing], Pennsylvania Association of Private School Administrators *[http://www.citytowninfo.com/school-profiles/pennco-tech-blackwood Pennco Tech City Town School Demographics], City Town Info website {{coord|40.09780|-74.87105|type:edu_globe:earth_region:US-PA|display=title}} [[Category:Universities and colleges in New Jersey]] [[Category:Universities and colleges in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1973]] [[Category:For-profit universities and colleges in the United States]] [[Category:Technical schools]] [[Category:Vocational education in the United States]] [[Category:Universities and colleges in Camden County, New Jersey]] [[Category:Universities and colleges in Bucks County, Pennsylvania]] [[Category:1973 establishments in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Gloucester Township, New Jersey]]

revision.text:
{{Expand Russian|date=May 2015}} '''"Putin. War"''' ({{lang-ru|Путин. Война}}) is a report based on materials prepared by the Russian opposition politician [[Boris Nemtsov]] about the [[2014–15 Russian military intervention in Ukraine]]. Published on the website ''Putin. Itogi'' on 12 May 2015, it covers the preparations for the [[annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation]] and the involvement of Russian troops in the [[war in Donbass]]. The report includes testimonials of Russian soldiers taken prisoner in Ukraine and photos of Russian military personnel who died in the hostilities. ==Authors== [[Boris Nemtsov]] began working on the report at the end of January 2015. After [[Assassination of Boris Nemtsov|Nemtsov's assassination]], his close associate [[Ilya Yashin]] headed a team of opposition journalists and activists, who continued writing the report and prepared it for publication. [[File:2015-03-01 Шествие памяти Немцова L1520063 Путин — это война.jpg|300px|thumb|"Putin is war"]] ==Structure and content== The [[Epigraph (literature)|epigraph]] of the report is a post by Boris Nemtsov in Facebook on 31 January 2015:https://www.facebook.com/boris.nemtsov/posts/758395224230080
The task of the opposition today is education and truth.
And the truth is that Putin is war and crisis.
The report consists of a preface, 11 chapters and a conclusion. It has 65 large-format pages with 46 color photographs and 8 charts. Chapters: #Why [[Vladimir Putin|Putin]] needs this war #Lies and propaganda #How they took Crimea #The Russian military in the east of Ukraine #Volunteers or mercenaries? #[[Cargo 200 (code name)|Cargo 200]] #Vladimir Putin's Army Depot #Who shot down the [[Malaysia Airlines Flight 17|Boeing]] #Who rules the Donbass #The humanitarian disaster #What does the war with Ukraine cost? Chapters cover the events from the beginning of [[Euromaidan]] when the [[Kremlin]] developed plans for the "annexation of Crimea" up to the start of 2015. The report includes information from relatives of Russian servicemen who died in Ukraine. The authors write that Putin's "[[Hybrid warfare|hybrid war]]" involves [[doublethink]], falsehoods and сowardliness, concluding:
The cowardly and despicable war unleashed by Putin will cost the country a lot. We will be paying for this adventure with the lives of our soldiers, economic crisis and political isolation. We will pay with enmity from our long-time allies. No people are closer and more like kin to the Russians than the Ukrainians. These are our brothers - without any pathos -- and the war between [[Russians in Ukraine|Russians]] and Ukrainians in Donbass is impossible to characterize in any other way except as fratricide. This war is the shame of our country. But the problem will not go away by itself. Putin must be stopped. And this can only be done by the Russian people themselves. Let us stop this war together.
==English version== A special issue of the ''European Union Foreign Affairs Journal'' (EUFAJ) from Germany includes an English translation of the entire report as well as the original text in [[Russian language|Russian]] (publication date 21.05.2015). An American [[Non-governmental organization|NGO]], the Free Russia Foundation, also published a translation of the report into English. It was presented on 28 May 2015 at the [[Atlantic Council]] in [[Washington, D.C.]][http://www.4freerussia.org/event/dc-report-release-boris-nemtsovs-putin-war-and-hiding-in-plain-sight-putins-war-in-ukraine-2/ REPORT RELEASE: Boris Nemtsov’s Putin. War and Hiding in Plain Sight: Putin’s War in Ukraine] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518084120/http://www.4freerussia.org/event/dc-report-release-boris-nemtsovs-putin-war-and-hiding-in-plain-sight-putins-war-in-ukraine-2/ |date=2015-05-18 }}[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eU0kuHI6lNg Release of two independently produced reports: "Hiding in Plain Sight" and Boris Nemtsov's "Putin. War", the Atlantic Council and the Free Russia Foundation, 28 May 2015 (YouTube video).][http://www.atlanticcouncil.org/events/webcasts/hiding-in-plain-sight-putin-s-war-in-ukraine-and-boris-nemtsov-s-putin-war Atlantic Council - "Hiding in Plain Sight: Putin's War in Ukraine and Boris Nemtsov's Putin. War."] ==Reactions== In Russia, 14 printing companies refused to publish the report. [[PayPal]] blocked an account raising funds for the report. ===Statement to the Prosecutor General=== The head of the NGO "Officers of Russia" Anton Tsvetkov sent a statement to the [[Prosecutor General of Russia|Prosecutor General of the Russian Federation]] with a request to verify the report "Putin. War" for the presence of false information. Tsvetkov said that the facts in the report are based on distorted and anti-Russian sources.[http://izvestia.ru/news/586484 Генпрокуратура проверит «доклад Немцова» на клевету] // Известия. — 2015. — 15 мая. ==References== {{Reflist|refs= {{cite news|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/russia-nemtsov-report-ukraine-war/27011532.html|title=Nemtsov Report Says More Than 200 Russian Soldiers Killed In Ukraine War|work=[[Radio Free Europe]]|date= May 2015}} {{cite news|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/nemtsov-report-on-putin-ukraine-war-to-be-released/27007353.html|title= Nemtsov's Report On Putin And Ukraine War Finally In Print, With A Little Help From His Friends|work=[[Radio Free Europe]]|date= May 2015}} {{cite news|url=http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/nemtsov-report-details-human-and-financial-costs-of-war-in-ukraine/520571.html|title=Nemtsov Report Details Human and Financial Costs of War in Ukraine|work=Moscow Times|date=12 May 2015 }} {{cite news|url=https://meduza.io/en/feature/2015/05/13/it-s-putin-s-war-for-power-and-money|title=‘It’s Putin’s war for power and money’ What the Nemtsov Report says about the Russia’s role in Ukraine’s war|work=Meduza.io|date=13 May 2015}} {{cite news|url=http://top.rbc.ru/politics/12/05/2015/555219649a7947b3394196d3|title=14 типографий отказались печатать доклад "Путин. Война"|language=Russian|trans-title=14 presses declined to print Putin.War report|first=Zhanna|last=Ulyanova|first2=Mikhail|last2=Rubin|work=rbc.ru|date= 12 May 2015 }} {{cite news|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/paypal-russia-nemtsov-report-ukraine/27016665.html|title=PayPal Blocks Russian Account For Nemtsov Report On Ukraine War|first=Carl|last=Schreck|work=[[Radio Free Europe]]|date=14 May 2015}} {{cite report |url= http://4freerussia.org/putin.war/Putin.War-Eng.pdf |title= Putin. War – Based on materials from Boris Nemtsov |first= Boris |last= Nemtsov |authorlink1= Boris Nemtsov |first2= Ilya |last2= Yashin |first3= Olga |last3= Shorina |publisher= Free Russia Foundation |date= May 2015 }} {{cite report |first=Boris |last= Nemtsov |url=http://www.libertas-institut.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/EUFAJ-Special-NemtsovReport-150521.pdf|format=PDF|title="Putin. The War", about the Involvement of Russia in the Eastern Ukraine conflict and the Crimea|publisher=European Union Foreign Affairs Journal|issue=Special Edition May 2015}} }} ==Links== * [http://4freerussia.org/putin.war/Putin.War-Eng.pdf Putin. War] {{ref-en}} *[http://www.putin-itogi.ru/putin-voina/ Доклад Немцова] on putin-itogi.ru {{ref-ru}} *[https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B4SOYKcoF01KbERJUm1HaTJiUWs/view pdf-file of investigation] on [[Google Drive]] {{ref-ru}} *http://www.economist.com/news/europe/21651130-posthumously-completed-report-details-russias-involvement-war-ukraine-boris-nemtsovs *http://www.rferl.org/content/nemtsov-report-on-putin-ukraine-war-to-be-released/27007353.html {{Vladimir Putin}} [[Category:Anti-war]] [[Category:Opposition to Vladimir Putin]] [[Category:People's Freedom Party]] [[Category:Russia–Ukraine relations]] [[Category:Vladimir Putin]] [[Category:War in Donbass]] [[Category:Whistleblowing]] [[Category:2015 works]] [[Category:2015 in Russia]]

{{Infobox person | name = Rod Masterson | image = | caption = | imagesize = | birth_date ={{birth date|1945|2|14}} | birth_place =[[Alexandria, Louisiana|Alexandria]], [[Rapides Parish, Louisiana|Rapides Parish]]
[[Louisiana]], USA | occupation = [[Actor]] | yearsactive = 1977–1998 | death_place=[[Baton Rouge, Louisiana|Baton Rouge]], Louisiana | death_date={{death date and age|2013|9|12|1945|2|14}} | death_cause=[[Parkinson's disease]] | resting_place= | spouse=Never married | birth_name =Rodney Gregory Masterson, Jr. | alma_mater=[[Louisiana State University]] | othername = | website = }} '''Rodney Gregory Masterson, Jr.''', known as '''Rod Masterson''' (February 14, 1945 – September 12, 2013), was an American film and television actor from [[Baton Rouge, Louisiana|Baton Rouge]], [[Louisiana]]. ==Background== A native of [[Alexandria, Louisiana|Alexandria]] in [[Central Louisiana]], Masterson was one of four children born to the late Rodney Masterson, Sr., a physician originally from [[St. Louis, Missouri|St. Louis]], [[Missouri]], and Elizabeth F. Masterson, a native of [[Jonesboro, Louisiana|Jonesboro]] in [[Jackson Parish, Louisiana|Jackson Parish]] in [[North Louisiana]]. He graduated in 1963 from [[Holy Savior Menard Central High School]], a [[Roman Catholic]]-institution in Alexandria and in 1967 from [[Louisiana State University]] in Baton Rouge. He served in the [[United States Marine Corps]], first as a drill sergeant and rose to the rank of [[lieutenant]] during the [[Vietnam War]] and was a member of the [[Veterans of Foreign Wars]].{{cite web|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/thetowntalk/obituary.aspx?pid=166943268#fbLoggedOut|title=Rodney G. Masterson, Jr.|publisher=''[[The Town Talk (Alexandria)|Alexandria Daily Town Talk]]''|accessdate=September 15, 2013}} In addition to his acting, Masterson operated a [[Bikram Yoga]] clinic in Baton Rouge.{{cite web|url=http://www.bikramyoga.com/BikramYoga/SciaticaOvercomingPain.php|title=Sciatica - Overcoming the Pain|publisher=bikramyoga.com|accessdate=September 16, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921002025/http://www.bikramyoga.com/BikramYoga/SciaticaOvercomingPain.php|archivedate=September 21, 2013|df=}} ==Acting career== Masterson made his screen debut in the [[NBC]]{{cite web|url=http://www.e-yearbook.com/yearbooks/lsu/1977/Page_196.html|title=''Louisiana State University Gumbo'', p. 196|publisher=e-yearbook.com|accessdate=September 16, 2013}} [[television film]], ''The Life and Assassination of the Kingfish'', which aired on March 21, 1977. It is written and [[Film director|directed]] by Robert Lee Collins. Masterson was cast as Murphy Roden, one of several bodyguards of then [[U.S. Senator]] [[Huey Long|Huey Pierce Long, Jr.]] Roden fired at close range upon [[Carl Austin Weiss]], the Baton Rouge physician and Long's presumed assassin, at the [[Louisiana State Capitol]] on the night of September 8, 1935.{{cite web|url=http://www.shreveporttimes.com/assets/pdf/D92445320.PDF|title=Mike Hasten, New book rekindles argument over H. P. Long's death, March 20, 2005|publisher=''[[The Times (Shreveport)|Shreveport Times]]''|accessdate=September 15, 2013}} [[Ed Asner]] plays Long in the film; Diane Kagan, [[Rose McConnell Long]]; and Steven Ramay, the teenaged son, [[Russell B. Long]].{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0076314/?ref_=nm_flmg_act_13|title=The Life and Assassination of the Kingfish|publisher=[[Internet Movie Data Base]]|accessdate=September 15, 2013}} In 1978, Masterson was cast as Oscar Weinberg in the episode "Rosendahl and Gilda Stern Are Dead" on [[James Garner]]'s NBC [[detective]] [[television series]], ''[[The Rockford Files]]''. That same year he had minor parts on [[CBS]]'s ''[[Lou Grant]]'', starring Ed Asner in the title role, and ''[[David Cassidy: Man Under Cover]]'', a ten-episode [[crime drama]] on NBC starring [[David Cassidy]].{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0557755/|title=Rod Masterson|publisher=Internet Movie Data Base|accessdate=September 15, 2013}} In 1979, Masterson played an unnamed police officer in the film ''Walk Proud'', starring [[Robby Benson]] as a confused [[Chicano]] gang member. The script of the film was written by Evan Hunter who had penned [[Glenn Ford]]'s ''[[The Blackboard Jungle]]'' twenty-five years earlier.{{cite web|url=http://movies.tvguide.com/walk-proud/cast/122294|title=Walk Proud|publisher=''[[TV Guide]]''|accessdate=September 16, 2013}} Masterson was cast as Patrolman Gallo in the 1984 film, ''[[Tightrope (film)|Tightrope]]'', starring [[Clint Eastwood]] and [[Jennifer Beck]], the story of attacks on [[prostitute]]s in [[New Orleans, Louisiana|New Orleans]].{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0088272/fullcredits?ref_=tt_cl_sm#cast|title=Full cast and crew for Tightrope (1984)|publisher=Internet Movie Data Base|accessdate=September 15, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.blockbuster.com/browse/catalog/personDetails/40840|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130916155033/http://www.blockbuster.com/browse/catalog/personDetails/40840|dead-url=yes|archive-date=September 16, 2013|title=Rod Masterson Movies|publisher=blockbuster.com|accessdate=September 16, 2013}} In 1987, he played the character Couch in ''[[A Gathering of Old Men (film)|A Gathering of Old Men]]'', the story of a group of elderly [[African-American]]s who rally to the defense of a fellow black charged with the murder of a white [[tenant farmer]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/person/124508%7C0/Rod-Masterson/filmography-with-synopsis.html|title=Rod Masterson|publisher=Turner Classic Movies|accessdate=September 16, 2013}} In 1988, he played the character Morris in the two-part pilot for the [[Carroll O'Connor]] NBC crime drama series, ''[[In the Heat of the Night (TV series)|In the Heat of the Night]]''. On October 23, 1989, he appeared as Dr. Nystrom in the television movie, ''False Witness'', filmed in New Orleans, the story of a woman assistant district attorney who seeks to convict the killer of a controversial [[talk show]] hostess. In 1989, he was cast as a prison guard in the film ''The Outside Woman'', starring [[Sharon Gless]] as a millworker who becomes a pen pal of a [[Louisiana State Penitentiary]] inmate, played by [[Scott Glenn]]. That same year, Masterson was cast one of two unnamed newspaper reporters of the ''[[The Town Talk (Alexandria)|Alexandria Daily Town Talk]]'' in the film, ''[[Blaze (1989 film)|Blaze]]'', a fictionalized account of Louisiana [[governor of Louisiana|Governor]] [[Earl Kemp Long]], played by [[Paul Newman]] and his involvement with stripper [[Blaze Starr]], played by [[Lolita Davidovich]]. In 1992, Masterson played the part of Crawford in the film, ''[[Delta Heat]]'', a police drama set in swampy terrain north of New Orleans, starring [[Anthony Edwards]].{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0104080/?ref_=nm_flmg_act_3|title=Delta Heat|publisher=Internet Movie Data Base|accessdate=September 15, 2013}}{{cite web|url=https://movies.nytimes.com/person/46329/Rod-Masterson|title=Rod Masterson|publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'', 2010|accessdate=September 16, 2013}} In 1994, he had a minor role as a reporter in the film, ''[[Blue Sky (film)|Blue Sky]]'', with [[Tommy Lee Jones]], [[Jessica Lange]] and [[Powers Boothe]], a drama about 1950s weapons testing in the United States.{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0109306/?ref_=nm_flmg_act_2|title=Blue Sky (1994)|publisher=Internet Movie Data Base|accessdate=September 15, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.fandango.com/rodmasterson/overview/p46329|title=Rod Masterson Filmography|publisher=fandango.com|accessdate=September 16, 2013}} Masterson's last role was as Ann's father in the 1998 film ''Dangerous Proposition'', filmed in Baton Rouge. In the story line a wife tries to determine if her husband is engaged in an affair by hiring another woman to entice him into [[adultery]] and to record the encounter. ==Death== Masterson died in Baton Rouge in 2013 at the age of sixty-eight after having been stricken for some fifteen years with [[Parkinson's disease]].Statement of Michael Masterson, brother of Rod Masterson, September 18, 2013 He is survived by two brothers, Michael Masterson (born 1946) of [[Thibodaux, Louisiana|Thibodaux]] in [[Lafourche Parish, Louisiana|Lafourche Parish]] in south Louisiana and John Lloyd Masterson (born 1955) of Alexandria, and a sister, Mary Elizabeth Masterson (born 1949) of [[Hendersonville, Tennessee|Hendersonville]], [[Tennessee]]. He was predeceased by a brother, Paul F. Masterson. ==Filmography== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year ! Title ! Role ! Notes |- |1979|| ''[[Walk Proud]]'' || Policeman #2 || |- |1984|| ''[[Tightrope (film)|Tightrope]]'' || Patrolman Gallo || |- |1989|| ''[[Blaze (1989 film)|Blaze]]'' || Town Talk Reporter #1 || |- |1992|| ''[[Delta Heat]]'' || Crawford || |- |1994|| ''[[Blue Sky (film)|Blue Sky]]'' || Reporter #2 || |- |1998|| ''Dangerous Proposition'' || Ann's Father || (final film role) |} ==External links== *{{IMDb name|0557755}} ==References== {{Portal|Louisiana|Film|Television|United States Marine Corps}} {{reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Masterson, Rod}} [[Category:1945 births]] [[Category:2013 deaths]] [[Category:American male film actors]] [[Category:American male television actors]] [[Category:Yoga teachers]] [[Category:People from Alexandria, Louisiana]] [[Category:Holy Savior Menard Central High School alumni]] [[Category:Male actors from Baton Rouge, Louisiana]] [[Category:Louisiana State University alumni]] [[Category:United States Marine Corps officers]] [[Category:American military personnel of the Vietnam War]] [[Category:Deaths from Parkinson's disease]]

revision.text:
{{update|date=March 2018}} The '''Rowman & Littlefield Award in Innovative Teaching''' is the only national teaching award in [[political science]] given in the [[United States]].<ref name=GMU-Mayer>{{cite web|url=http://policy.gmu.edu/faculty/mayer/index.html|title=Jeremy Mayer, Associate, Professor and Director, Master's of Public Policy program|publisher=[[George Mason University School of Public Policy|School of Public Policy]] of [[George Mason University]]|accessdate=2008-07-12|date=2008-03-10}}</ref> It has been awarded annually by the [[American Political Science Association]]<ref name=APSA-VanVechten>{{cite web|url=http://www.apsanet.org/content_53678.cfm|title=Professor Van Vechten Named to Receive 2008 Roman ''{{black|(sic)}}'' & Littlefield Award |publisher=[[American Political Science Association]] |accessdate=2008-07-12 |date=2008-07-12}}</ref> and was first awarded in 1996.<ref name=APSA-Rowman>{{cite web|url=http://www.apsanet.org/section_481.cfm|title=Rowman & Littlefield Award for Innovative Teaching in Political Science|publisher=[[American Political Science Association]] |accessdate=2008-07-12 |date=2008-07-12}}</ref>
The award is sponsored by [[Rowman & Littlefield|Rowman & Littlefield Publishers]]. It carries a [[US Dollar|US$]]500 cash [[stipend]] and is presented at the APSA's Annual Meeting to a winner selected from political science professors nominated by members of the award committee, chaired by L. Sandy Maisel, Professor of Government and Director of the [[Goldfarb Center for Public Affairs and Civic Engagement]] at [[Colby College]] in [[Waterville, Maine|Waterville]], [[Maine]].<ref name=APSA-Rowman />
According to the Association, the Award recognizes developers of "effective new approaches to teaching" among political scientists. Its intent is to honor a wide range of new directions, rather than one in particular. The annual winner is chosen from among a pool of nominees whose innovations had moved [[political science]] [[pedagogy]] forward.<ref name=APSA-VanVechten />
==Recipients==
===2008=== The 2008 award was presented to Professor [[Renée Van Vechten]] of the [[University of Redlands]] Department of Government. Van Vechten received the award for work done on collaborative simulations; she created and facilitated three simultaneous interactive simulations, one where her students simulated [[Member of Congress|Members of Congress]] in her Congress course and two in her Introduction to American Governments courses, with one class playing lobbyists and the other playing the constituents of the Congressmembers.<ref name=APSA-VanVechten /><ref name=APSA-Rowman />
===2007=== Professors [[James Meernik]] and [[Kimi King]] of the [[University of North Texas]] for their jointly taught study abroad class entitled ''[[International Law]]: Peace and Justice'', an intensive three-week program at the [[International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia]] (ICTY) in [[The Hague]], [[Netherlands]]. Students receive access to top officials, including two of the ICTY presidents and 10 of the ICTY judges, as well as to attorneys and to tribunal testimony.<ref name=APSA-Rowman />
===2005=== The 2005 winner was Professor Barbara Allen of [[Carleton College]].<ref name=APSA-Rowman />
[[Jeremy Mayer]], a [[professor]] of [[public policy]] and [[political science]] at the [[George Mason University School of Public Policy|School of Public Policy]] of [[George Mason University]], is a past winner of the Award.<ref name=GMU-Mayer />
== References == <references />
{{DEFAULTSORT:Rowman and Littlefield Award in Innovative Teaching}} [[Category:Political science]] [[Category:Academic awards]] [[Category:Politics awards]] [[Category:American education awards]] [[Category:Teacher awards]]

{{Infobox company | name = Rules-of-Renovation | logo = | industry = Real estate | predecessor = <!-- or: | predecessors = --> | successor = <!-- or: | successors = --> | founded = <!-- if known: {{Start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} in [[city]], [[state]], [[country]] --> | founder = [[Hilary Farr]] | defunct = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | hq_location_city = | hq_location_country = | area_served = <!-- or: | areas_served = --> | key_people = | services = Educational program | owner = <!-- or: | owners = --> | parent = | website = {{URL|rulesofrenovation.com}} }}
'''Rules-of-Renovation''' is an educational program that provides training in the [[real estate]] world, specifically home renovation. This program is designed by [[HGTV]] star, [[Hilary Farr]] from ''[[Love It or List It]]''. Farr has many years of experience in real estate and interior design, and has designed Rules of Renovation to help others be successful in the renovation of houses.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://undercoverrealestate.com/rules-of-renovation-hilary-farr/|title=Rules of Renovation: Hilary Farr|website=Undercover Real Estate|accessdate=27 February 2018}}</ref><ref>http://www.scamsites.com/review/rules-of-renovation/</ref>
==History== Hilary Farr is originally from Canada and was introduced to the real estate world at a young age, by helping her mother decorate her childhood home. Farr was able to move to Los Angeles, where she bought several properties and renovated them. In the beginning, she was working part time jobs, but after a few years her talent for renovation of homes started to gain recognition.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/stage/2016/05/26/hilary-farr-the-new-villainess-in-ross-petty-panto.html|title=‘Love It Or List It’ host the new villainess in Ross Petty panto|first=Bruce|last=DeMara|date=26 May 2016|publisher=|accessdate=27 February 2018|via=Toronto Star}}</ref><ref>https://realtytimes.com/advicefromtheexpert/item/1014716-buying-an-old-home-5-steps-to-make-sure-your-renovation-is-effective?rtmpage=lizzieweakley</ref><ref>http://www.nicehomelive.com/old-home-renovations-how-to-update-your-master-bedroom/</ref>
In 2008, Farr was approached by the [[W Network]] to co-host the show ''[[Love It or List It]]'', along with [[David Visentin]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://notablelife.com/hilary-farr-redirect-anger-and-be-grateful-for-the-bad/|title=Hilary Farr: Redirect Anger and be Grateful for the Bad - Notable Life|date=17 May 2013|publisher=|accessdate=27 February 2018}}</ref> The show was broadcast on HGTV and the W Network. The show was originally based in Toronto, but in 2014, ''Love It or List It'' began its filming in North Carolina.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vh1.com/news/84797/hilary-farr-talks-about-love-it-or-list-it/|title=Hilary Farr On Mean Homeowners, Hoarders, And Famous Homes She'd Love Or List|publisher=|accessdate=27 February 2018}}</ref> Hilary Farr co-founded Rules of Renovation to give investors unique strategies on how to successfully renovate homes and then sell them. Investors looking to succeed in the field were invited to register for a free event to see how Rules of Renovation could help their business.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://rulesofrenovation.com/about/|title=Rules of Renovation details|publisher=|accessdate=27 February 2018}}</ref>
==Concept== While renovating houses and then selling them has became a way for people to make a living, it did not mean that the process is without risk. An investor without the correct tools and strategies has a high chance of making mistakes and failing in the field. Rules of Renovation exploited this market by giving investors the tools for being successful using its trained coaches and their tactics.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/02/05/house-flipping-is-back-with-all-its-opportunities-and-risks.html|title=House flipping is making a comeback, and that has some people nervous|first=Trent|last=Gillies|date=5 February 2017|publisher=|accessdate=27 February 2018}}</ref><ref>http://rismedia.com/2017/09/18/real-estate-deal-breakers-how-fix-them-efficiently/</ref>
This educational program has several different steps offered to investors. First, it starts with a free renovation training event that discusses the basics and shows investors how the program would help them to succeed in their renovations. The second step is a 3-Day Workshop that provides attendees with strategies tailored to each individual. The last step is the ongoing mentoring and coaching. Even after the investors leave the event, they would have access to the coaches and one-on-one trainings for future questions.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://rulesofrenovation.com/faq/|title=Rules of Renovation|publisher=|accessdate=27 February 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== *[https://rulesofrenovation.com/ Official website]
[[Category:Educational programs]]

{{Software development process}} The '''''Software Engineering Body of Knowledge''''' ('''SWEBOK''') is an international standard ISO/IEC TR 19759:2005<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iso.org/iso/iso_catalogue/catalogue_tc/catalogue_detail.htm?csnumber=33897|title=ISO/IEC TR 19759:2005 |accessdate=2013-04-01}}</ref> specifying a guide to the generally accepted Software Engineering Body of Knowledge.
The Guide to the Software Engineering Body of Knowledge (SWEBOK Guide) has been created through cooperation among several professional bodies and members of industry and is published by the [[IEEE Computer Society]] ([[IEEE]]).<ref>"Guide to the software engineering body of knowledge : 2004 version," Library of Congress Online Catalog, 2005, http://lccn.loc.gov/2005921729. Retrieved 16 July 2013.</ref> The standard can be accessed freely from the [[IEEE Computer Society]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.computer.org/portal/web/swebok/home |title=SWEBOK |publisher=Computer.org |date= |accessdate=2014-01-31}}</ref> In late 2013, SWEBOK V3 was approved for publication and released.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.computer.org/portal/web/pressroom/New-Version-of-Guide-to-the-Software-Engineering-Body-of-Knowledge-Approved |title=New Version of Guide to the Software Engineering Body of Knowledge Approved | accessdate=2014-01-31}}</ref> In 2016, the IEEE Computer Society kicked off the SWEBoK Evolution effort to develop future iterations of the body of knowledge.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.computer.org/web/peb/swebok-evolution |title=SWEBoK Evolution | accessdate=2017-02-21}}</ref>
== SWEBOK Version 3== The published version of SWEBOK V3 has the following 15 [[knowledge area]]s (KAs) within the field of [[software engineering]]:
* [[Software requirements]] * [[Software design]] * [[Software construction]] * [[Software testing]] * [[Software maintenance]] * [[Software configuration management]] * [[Software engineering management]] * [[Software engineering process]] * [[Software engineering]] models and methods * [[Software quality]] * [[Software engineering professional practice]] * [[Software engineering economics]] * Computing foundations * Mathematical foundations * Engineering foundations
It also recognized, but did not define, these related disciplines:
* [[Computer engineering]] * [[Systems engineering]] * [[Project management]] * [[Quality management]] * General [[management]] * [[Computer science]] * [[Mathematics]]
== 2004 Edition of the SWEBOK == The 2004 edition of the SWEBOK guide defined ten [[knowledge area]]s (KAs) within the field of [[software engineering]]: * [[Software requirements]] * [[Software design]] * [[Software construction]] * [[Software testing]] * [[Software maintenance]] * [[Software configuration management]] * Software engineering management ([[Engineering management]]) * [[Software engineering process]] * [[Software engineering tools and methods]] * [[Software quality]]
The SWEBOK also defines disciplines related to software engineering: * [[Computer engineering]] * [[Computer science]] * [[Management]] * [[Mathematics]] * [[Project management]] * [[Quality management]] * Software ergonomics ([[Cognitive ergonomics]]) * [[Systems engineering]]
== Similar Efforts == A similar effort to define a body of knowledge for software engineering is the "Computing Curriculum Software Engineering (CCSE)," officially named [[Software Engineering 2004]] (SE2004). The curriculum largely overlaps with the 2004 SWEBOK V2 because the SWEBOK has been used as one of its sources; however, it is more directed towards academia. Whereas the [[SWEBOK]] Guide defines the [[software engineering]] knowledge that practitioners should have after four years of practice, SE2004 defines the knowledge that an [[undergraduate]] software engineering student should possess upon graduation (including knowledge of mathematics, general engineering principles, and other related areas). SWEBOK V3 aims to address these intersections.
==See also== *[[Project Management Body of Knowledge]] (PMBOK) *[[Enterprise Architecture Body of Knowledge]] (EABOK) *[[Business Analysis Body of Knowledge]] (BABOK) *[[Automation]] Body of Knowledge (ABOK) *[[Data management|Data Management]] Body of Knowledge (DMBOK) *[[ISO/IEC JTC 1/SC 7]]
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == * {{official website|http://www.computer.org/web/swebok/home}}
{{Software engineering}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Software Engineering Body Of Knowledge}} [[Category:Software engineering publications]] [[Category:Bodies of knowledge]] [[Category:Computer science education]]

page.title: St. Catherine's Master of Physician Assistant Studies (MPAS) Program

revision.text:
'''St. Catherine's Master of Physician Assistant Studies (MPAS) Program''' is accredited by the [http://www.arc-pa.org/ ARC-PA]<ref name=stkates>{{cite web|title=St.Catherine's MPAS article|url=http://www.stkate.edu/scan/12-oct/feature/great_expectations.php|accessdate=21 October 2014}}</ref> The program is located on the [[Saint Paul, Minnesota]] campus of [[St. Catherine University]] . The program is one of the three accredited Master of Physician Assistant Studies programs in the state of [[Minnesota]]. The other two programs are located at [[Bethel University (Minnesota)|Bethel University]] and [[Augsburg University]]. St .Catherine's MPAS program aims to educate and prepare its students to become successful [[Physician Assistants]].
Their mission statement is: ''"Influenced by Catholic intellectual tradition, the MPAS program is committed to preparing competent and compassionate Physician Assistant scholar practitioners who possess the knowledge, clinical acumen and critical thinking skills necessary to practice exemplary, ethical, patient-centered care, and who will lead and influence with grace emphasizing global responsibility, social justice and the preservation of human dignity."''<ref>{{cite web |title= St.Catherine's MPAS site |url= https://www2.stkate.edu/mpas/home |accessdate= 21 October 2014}}</ref>
The MPAS Program is full-time, containing 110 credits of in-classroom study and over 2,000 clinical hours over the span of 28 months.<ref name=degree>{{cite web|title=St.Catherine's MPAS Site-Degree|url=https://www2.stkate.edu/mpas/degree|accessdate=21 October 2014}}</ref> Each term follows a model that contains a specific sequence of courses.<ref name=degree /> The first 14 months consist of classroom instruction/learning, and the following 14 months, clinical education. Students then finish the program with a senior seminar.<ref name=degree /> During the 14 months of [[clinical clerkship]], students complete nine clinical clerkships at various locations and medical specialties. Two of the nine clerkships are considered electives, and students are able to customize their education by choosing an area of interest.<ref name=degree />
There are particular prerequisite courses and steps for admission into the program, which are outlined and can be found on the [https://www2.stkate.edu/mpas/apply St. Catherine MPAS website.] Applicants should have a [[Bachelor's degree]] , a minimum GPA of 3.2, and experience in the healthcare field. This includes a minimum of 250 logged hours in a healthcare setting, although most successful applicants have about 500 hours.<ref>{{cite web|title=St.Catherine's MPAS site-application|url=https://www2.stkate.edu/mpas/apply|accessdate=21 October 2014}}</ref> In addition, students must meet the [https://www2.stkate.edu/mpas/technical-standards technical standards] provided by [[St.Catherine University.]] Admission to Physician Assistant programs is highly competitive.
'''Fall 2013 Admission Facts''' *Number of Applicants: 147 *Class Size: 32 *Acceptance Rate: 22% *Overall Undergraduate GPA: 3.44 *Undergraduate Prerequesite Course GPA: 3.43 *GRE Verbal: 153 *GRE Quantitative: 151 *GRE Analytical Writing: 4.0
After completing the 28-month program, students must take the [[Physician Assistant National Certifying Exam|PANCE]] certification test. The PANCE is five hours long, containing 300 multiple choice questions. The pass rate, mean score, and national mean score of the St. Catherine's MPAS program will be posted when available.<ref>{{cite web|last1=St. Kates MPAS Site|url=https://www2.stkate.edu/mpas/accreditation|accessdate=21 October 2014}}</ref> The inaugural Master of Physician Assistant Studies graduated from St. Catherine University in December 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www2.stkate.edu/mpas/accreditation|accessdate=21 October 2014}}</ref>
Heather Bidinger is the program director. Bidinger was hired in 2009 to form the curriculum for the program.<ref name=stkates /> A faculty directory can be found on the [https://www2.stkate.edu/mpas/faculty St. Catherine MPAS website.]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links==
[[Category:Health education]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox character | colour = #DEDEE2 | name = Sue Sylvester | series = [[Glee (TV series)|Glee]] | image = Sue Sylvester Glee.jpeg | caption = Jane Lynch as Sue Sylvester in season 2 of ''Glee'' | first = "[[Pilot (Glee)|Pilot]]" | last = "[[Dreams Come True (Glee)|Dreams Come True]]" | creator = [[Ryan Murphy (writer)|Ryan Murphy]]
[[Brad Falchuk]]
[[Ian Brennan (writer)|Ian Brennan]] | portrayer = [[Jane Lynch]] | occupation = [[Cheerleading|Cheerleading coach]]
TV news personality
Principal
Vice President of the United States | family = Doris Sylvester (mother)
Jean Sylvester (sister, deceased) | children= Robin Sylvester (daughter) }} '''Sue Sylvester''' is a [[fictional character]] of the [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] [[musical film|musical]] [[comedy-drama]] series, ''[[Glee (TV series)|Glee]]''. The character is portrayed by actress [[Jane Lynch]], and appears in ''Glee'' from its [[Pilot (Glee)|pilot episode]], first broadcast on May 19, 2009, through the show's [[Dreams Come True (Glee)|final episode]], first broadcast on March 25, 2015. Sue was developed by ''Glee'' creators [[Ryan Murphy (writer)|Ryan Murphy]], [[Brad Falchuk]], and [[Ian Brennan (writer)|Ian Brennan]]. For the show's first four seasons, Sue is the track-suit wearing coach of the William McKinley High School [[Cheerleader|cheerleading squad]], and a ruthless bully to both students and faculty members alike. Because her cheerleading squad competes with the [[glee club]] for the school's limited funding, she is often at odds with the club and more particularly its director [[Will Schuester]] ([[Matthew Morrison]]). Sue is the main antagonist throughout the series' run. In the show's [[Glee (season 5)|fifth season]], Sue is made the school's new principal, though she is ultimately fired late in the show's [[Glee (season 6)|sixth and final season]]. Due to Lynch's initial limited availability, Sue was originally set to be a recurring character while Lynch was working on a [[Damon Wayans]] [[pilot episode|pilot]] for the [[American Broadcasting Company]] (ABC). When that pilot fell through, Sue became a starring role. The character has been acclaimed by critics. Mary McNamara for the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' has written that "Lynch alone makes ''Glee'' worth watching", while ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''{{'s}} Ken Tucker has called Sue "the greatest [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]]-musical villain to ever co-star in a TV series". In recognition of her portrayal of Sue, Lynch won an [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Comedy Series|Emmy]] and a [[Golden Globe Award for Best Supporting Actress – Series, Miniseries or Television Film|Golden Globe Award]]. ==Storylines== ===Season 1=== [[File:Jane Lynch, 2008 appearance (crop).jpg|thumb|upright|Jane Lynch (''pictured'') plays Sue]] Throughout the [[Glee (season 1)|first season]] of ''Glee'', Sue makes numerous attempts at sabotaging the William McKinley High School [[glee club]], New Directions. She enlists members of her cheerleading squad, the Cheerios, to bring the club down from the inside,{{cite episode |title=Showmance |episodelink=Showmance |series=Glee |serieslink=Glee (TV series) |credits=[[Ryan Murphy (writer)|Ryan Murphy]] (director, writer), [[Brad Falchuk]] (writer), Ian Brennan (writer) |network=[[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] |airdate=September 9, 2009 |season=1 |number=2}} and conspires to lure away its star member, [[Rachel Berry (Glee)|Rachel Berry]] ([[Lea Michele]]).{{cite episode |title=Preggers |episodelink=Preggers |series=Glee |serieslink=Glee (TV series) |credits=[[Brad Falchuk]] (director, writer) |network=[[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] |airdate=September 23, 2009 |season=1 |number=4}} Sue is appointed co-director of the club by [[Principal Figgins]] ([[Iqbal Theba]]),{{cite episode |title=Vitamin D |episodelink=Vitamin D (Glee)|series=Glee |serieslink=Glee (TV series) |credits=[[Elodie Keene]] (director), [[Ryan Murphy (writer)|Ryan Murphy]] (writer) |network=[[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] |airdate=October 7, 2009 |season=1 |number=6}} but soon scales back her involvement when her attempts to turn the club members against director [[Will Schuester]] ([[Matthew Morrison]]) fail.{{cite episode |title=Throwdown |episodelink=Throwdown (Glee)|series=Glee |serieslink=Glee (TV series) |credits= [[Ryan Murphy (writer)|Ryan Murphy]] (director), [[Brad Falchuk]] (writer)|network=[[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] |airdate=October 14, 2009 |season=1 |number=7}} Hoping to ruin the club's chances of winning at the [[show choir]] Sectionals competition, Sue gives New Directions' [[setlist]] to the directors of their rival glee clubs.{{cite episode |title=Hairography |episodelink=Hairography (Glee)|series=Glee |serieslink=Glee (TV series) |credits=[[Bill D'Elia]] (director), [[Ian Brennan (writer)|Ian Brennan]] (writer)|network=[[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] |airdate=November 25, 2010 |season=1 |number=11}} Despite having to devise a new setlist at the last moment, New Directions win by unanimous decision and Sue is suspended by Figgins.{{cite episode |title=Sectionals |episodelink=Sectionals|series=Glee |serieslink=Glee (TV series) |credits=[[Brad Falchuk]] (director, writer)|network=[[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] |airdate=December 9, 2009 |season=1 |number=13}} She blackmails him into allowing her back,{{cite episode |title=Hell-O|episodelink=Hell-O (Glee)|series=Glee |serieslink=Glee (TV series) |credits=[[Brad Falchuk]] (director), [[Ian Brennan (writer)|Ian Brennan]] (writer)|network=[[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] |airdate=April 13, 2010 |season=1 |number=14}} and is selected as a judge for the show choir Regionals competition. Sue is ridiculed by the other judges for her lack of fame and underdog status, allowing her to empathize with the glee club members. She votes for New Directions to win, and although they place last, she blackmails Figgins into allowing them another year to compete.{{cite episode |title=Journey|episodelink=Journey (Glee)|series=Glee |series-link=Glee (TV series) |credits=[[Brad Falchuk]] (director, writer) |network=[[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] |airdate=June 8, 2010 |season=1 |number=22}} Sue's personal life is also explored over the course of the season. She has a commentary feature on the local television news, "Sue's Corner", which she uses to editorialize on issues such as littering and support for [[caning]]. She falls in love with news anchor [[Characters of Glee#Rod Remington|Rod Remington]] (Bill A. Jones), but their burgeoning relationship comes to an abrupt end when she discovers he is sleeping with his co-anchor, Andrea Carmichael (Earlene Davis).{{cite episode |title=Mash-Up |episodelink=Mash-Up (Glee)|series=Glee |serieslink=Glee (TV series) |credits= [[Elodie Keene]] (director), [[Ian Brennan (writer)|Ian Brennan]] (writer)|network=[[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] |airdate=October 21, 2009 |season=1 |number=8}} In the episode "[[Wheels (Glee)|Wheels]]", Sue allows [[Becky Jackson]] (Lauren Potter), a [[Tenth grade#United States|sophomore]] with [[Down syndrome]], to join the Cheerios. Will is suspicious of her motives, increasingly so when Sue donates money to the school to fund three new ramps for students with disabilities. It is revealed that Sue's older sister Jean (Robin Trocki) also has Down syndrome, and lives in a residential care facility.{{cite episode |title=Wheels |episodelink=Wheels (Glee)|series=Glee |serieslink=Glee (TV series) |credits=[[Paris Barclay]] (director) [[Ryan Murphy (writer)|Ryan Murphy]] (writer)|network=[[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] |airdate=November 11, 2009 |season=1 |number=9}} Sue becomes a minor celebrity when [[Olivia Newton-John]] invites her to remake the video to "[[Physical (Olivia Newton-John song)|Physical]]", after a [[viral video]] of Sue [[Jazzercise|Jazzercising]] to the track achieves internet notoriety. She donates her share of the profits to her sister's care home.{{cite episode |title=Bad Reputation|episodelink=Bad Reputation (Glee)|series=Glee |series-link=Glee (TV series) |credits=[[Elodie Keene]] (director), [[Ian Brennan (writer)|Ian Brennan]] (writer)|network=[[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] |airdate=May 4, 2010 |season=1 |number=17}} ===Season 2=== At the onset of the [[Glee (season 2)|second season]], Sue has formed a truce with Will, and together they conspire against the school's new football coach, [[Shannon Beiste]] ([[Dot Jones]]). When Will comes to regret his actions and apologizes, Sue renews their enmity.{{cite episode |title=Audition|episodelink=Audition (Glee)|series=Glee |series-link=Glee (TV series) |credits=[[Brad Falchuk]] (director), [[Ian Brennan (writer)|Ian Brennan]] (writer) |network=[[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] |airdate=September 21, 2010 |season=2 |number=1}} She is appointed acting principal after having Figgins infected with the flu,{{cite episode |title=The Substitute|episodelink=The Substitute (Glee)|series=Glee |series-link=Glee (TV series) |credits=[[Ryan Murphy (writer)|Ryan Murphy]] (director), [[Ian Brennan (writer)|Ian Brennan]] (writer) |network=[[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] |airdate=November 16, 2010 |season=2 |number=7}} but although the school board is so impressed with her performance they make her position permanent, she resigns when they refuse to uphold her expulsion of [[Dave Karofsky]] ([[Max Adler (actor)|Max Adler]]), a bully who had threatened to kill glee club member [[Kurt Hummel]] ([[Chris Colfer]]).{{cite episode |title=Furt|episodelink=Furt|series=Glee |series-link=Glee (TV series) |credits=Carol Banker (director), [[Ryan Murphy (writer)|Ryan Murphy]] (writer)|network=[[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] |airdate=November 23, 2010 |season=2 |number=8}} After Sue learns that Rod and Andrea have become engaged, she announces her intention to marry herself. Her estranged mother Doris ([[Carol Burnett]]), a recently retired [[Nazi hunter]], visits in an attempt to make amends for her absentee parenting, but is continuously critical of her daughter, to the point that Sue disinvites her during her wedding ceremony. Doris leaves, and Sue and Jean comfort each other. Sue grows disillusioned with cheerleading, and in an effort to recapture her love for it, plans to fire cheerleader [[Brittany Pierce]] ([[Heather Morris]]) from a cannon during the team's next competitive routine. Brittany and her friends [[Santana Lopez]] ([[Naya Rivera]]) and [[Quinn Fabray]] ([[Dianna Agron]]) ultimately quit the squad, which loses at Regionals after having won the national title for six straight years. Sue is named Loser of the Year in a televised interview with [[Katie Couric]], and has her budget slashed. Depressed, Sue stages a fake suicide, and as she hoped would happen, is convinced to temporarily join the glee club to lift her spirits, though she really wants to bring down the club from within. When her attempts to do so fail, Sue decides to become the coach of Aural Intensity, one of New Directions' Regionals competitors, and deliberately injures their director in order to get the job. Sue is furious when her club loses to New Directions, and punches the announcer in the face.{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/culture/news/glee-recap-new-directions-head-to-regionals-in-original-song-20110316|title='Glee' Recap: New Directions Head to Regionals in 'Original Song'|last=Futterman|first=Erica|date=March 16, 2011|work=[[Rolling Stone (magazine)|Rolling Stone]]|publisher=[[Jann Wenner]]|accessdate=March 24, 2011}} More intent than ever on destroying the glee club, Sue forms a "League of Doom", which consists of former glee club director [[Sandy Ryerson]] ([[Stephen Tobolowsky]]), the coach of rival glee club Vocal Adrenaline, [[Dustin Goolsby]] ([[Cheyenne Jackson]]), and Will's ex-wife [[Terri Schuester]] ([[Jessalyn Gilsig]]). Their first mission, to ruin a New Directions benefit, fails when Sandy is won over by a performance from [[Mercedes Jones]] ([[Amber Riley]]) and donates the full amount needed. Devastated by Jean's death from pneumonia, Sue turns to Terri, who has the glee club's plane tickets for Nationals changed from New York to [[Tripoli]]. She also removes Becky from the Cheerios, because she reminds her of her sister. Kurt and his stepbrother [[Finn Hudson]] ([[Cory Monteith]]) help Sue to clean out Jean's things, and she accepts their offer to have New Directions perform at the funeral, as she is afraid no one else will come. At the well-attended funeral service, an emotional Sue is unable to continue reading her [[eulogy]] after a few sentences, and Will reads the remainder for her. Touched by his support, Sue tells Will he is a good friend and she will no longer go after the glee club. She will instead be running for the [[United States House of Representatives]] on a platform of lowering health care costs, as her sister had faced significantly higher bills in her last few years. She then apologizes to Becky, reinstates her as a member of the Cheerios, and tells her she will be captain of the squad next year. As a final act of reconciliation, Sue asks for and receives a hug from Becky. ===Season 3=== At the start of the [[Glee (season 3)|third season]], Sue's campaign for Congress is not going well. She decides to pledge to get rid of all arts programs in schools, music and theater especially, until all students are reading at or above grade level. Will's attempt to embarrass Sue and highlight the value of the arts by [[glitter bombing]] her backfires, and Sue's poll numbers rise. She also goes back on her promise to leave the glee club alone by having her new cheerleading co-captains, Becky and Santana, sabotage the club's recruitment drive. She rails against the school musical, and succeeds in having its funding rescinded. This angers Kurt's father, [[Burt Hummel]] ([[Mike O'Malley]]), who arranges for local businesses to sponsor the musical, and he enters the congressional race as a write-in candidate to defeat her. Sue runs a negative campaign, airing political ads containing false statements about Burt's personal life through her political ads. One of the other candidates in the race discovers that Santana is a lesbian, and uses this to attack Sue on the issue of "family values" for appointing her a cheerleading captain, and to imply that Sue herself is a lesbian. Santana is devastated, as she has not yet come out as a lesbian. Sue attempts to combat the implications by starting a relationship with one of her former bed partners, Ohio State football recruiter Cooter Menkins, who had recently been dating Coach Beiste. Being seen in public with Cooter does not help her in the voting, however; she comes in third, and Burt wins. In the episode "[[On My Way (Glee)|On My Way]]", Sue reveals she is pregnant, shocking everyone. Her child is revealed by doctors to be a girl, but they mention that there were abnormalities on the scan. Sue mentions to Becky that she will have a child just like her, hinting that the baby may have Down's Syndrome. She shows unusual compassion, telling Will she will help him win nationals, letting Quinn rejoin the Cheerios, and is visibly upset at Karofsky's suicide attempt. ===Season 4=== In the first episode of the [[Glee (season 4)|fourth season]], "[[The New Rachel]]", Sue, now a mother, introduces her newborn child named Robin to [[Kurt Hummel|Kurt]]. Sue then calls Kitty, a new cheerleader into her office to take Robin from her. Sue has a storyline with [[Alex Newell]]'s character, [[Wade Adams|Wade "Unique" Adams]], when she doesn't want him to audition for the role of Rizzo on the school's musical, ''[[Grease (musical)|Grease]]''. Also, when [[Finn Hudson|Finn]] insults Robin, calling her "retarded", they start a strong rivalry. Sue "proposes" to Finn that if New Directions lose sectionals, the glee club would end. They lose and Sue uses the choir room for the Cheerios practices when the weather is cold. When New Directions discover that they won because the other club cheated, Sue gives them back the choir room. Sue is fired from the William McKinley High School in "[[Shooting Star (Glee)|Shooting Star]]", when Becky's gun is shot by accident, causing everyone to think that there's a school shooting. Sue says it was her gun and she misfired it while checking it, to protect Becky. Coach Roz replaces Sue as the cheerleader squad coach and takes her office. Sue later starts working as a personal trainer, and [[Blaine Anderson|Blaine]] tries to get her back on McKinley's faculty, but she denies his offer by saying that getting fired was the best thing that could have ever happened to her, because now, as a trainer, people respect her, and also admits that she does not miss the Cheerios at all. ===Season 5=== In the episode "[[Love Love Love (Glee)|Love Love Love]]," Sue has come back to McKinley High after Becky confessed to the shooting. Upon her return, Sue gets Principal Figgins fired by faking incriminating details about him. He is demoted to janitor, while she takes his job as principal, where she constantly torments Figgins, and tells Will and Roz that she will keep the Cheerios and New Directions going if they win in their upcoming competitions. Following Finn's death in the episode "[[The Quarterback (Glee)|The Quarterback]]," Sue orders the memorial in the school to be taken down, which angers Santana to the point where she confronts her and pushes her into a filing cabinet. She later reveals, after Santana apologizes to her, she is heartbroken Finn died believing she hated him, while she actually respected him and looked forward to having him as a colleague. In "[[Puppet Master (Glee)|Puppet Master]]" She experiences a hallucination in the choir room, later to be a gas leak. After fixing the pipe herself, she then becomes the school's permanent principal. In "[[City of Angels (Glee)|City Of Angels]]", after New Directions comes in second in their Nationals competition, Sue fires Will and disbands the club, although she gets Will a job at Carmel High School as the new Coach for Vocal Adrenaline. ===Season 6=== In "[[A Wedding (Glee)|A Wedding]]", Sue tries to attend Brittany and Santana's wedding only to be flatly refused for her treatment of everyone. Showing a softer side, Sue visits Santana's grandmother who doesn't believe in two women marrying and uses "some reverse Suecology" to get the woman to see that no matter what she believes, family is most important. Sue is then allowed to attend the wedding and helps convince [[Kurt Hummel]] and [[Blaine Anderson]] to marry alongside Brittany and Santana, providing the rings for them when they don't have any. Sue later provides the two couples with their dream honeymoons, telling them that despite how she's treated them over the years, she's come to see them like her own kids. She is fired as principal in "[[The Rise and Fall of Sue Sylvester]]". By 2020, Sue is the Republican [[Vice President of the United States]] to President [[Jeb Bush]]. She is planning on running for President in 2024. She rededicates the McKinley High auditorium to be named in honor of Finn Hudson while apologizing for her previous poor perception of the glee club. McKinley High has now become a model of excellence and other schools are copying its format. New Directions members from years past and present unite for one last massive group song, with Sue and Becky (now working as Sue's bodyguard) joining the entire cast for one final bow. ==Development== ===Casting and creation=== Sue is played by Jane Lynch. The character did not exist when the script for the ''Glee'' pilot was first submitted to Fox. In an interview with ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'', Ryan Murphy said that Fox Entertainment president Kevin Reilly was responsible for her creation. {{" '}}On our first call, Kevin said, "You need a villain,{{" '}} Murphy remembered. 'And I said, "You know, you're right." I knew exactly who she is. I said, "Her name is Sue Sylvester. And she is the cheerleading coach. And she may be on horse estrogen.{{" ' "}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20386845,00.html |title={{-'}}Glee': The show heard round the world|last=Stack|first=Tim|date=May 21, 2010|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Time Inc.]]|accessdate=September 4, 2011}} The casting notice described Sue as "the anal, tightly wound, and ruthlessly ambitious leader of the Harrison High cheer leading squad."{{cite web|url=http://thefutoncritic.com/news.aspx?id=7825 |title=Development Update: Thursday, October 30|author=The Futon Critic Staff|date=October 30, 2008|work=thefutoncritic.com|accessdate=September 5, 2011}} At the time she was cast as Sue, Lynch was already committed to do a [[Damon Wayans]] [[pilot episode|pilot]] for [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]. The ''Glee'' role initially had her as a guest star, in the hope that she could become a regular in the future. When the ABC pilot fell through, Lynch became a series regular.{{cite web|url=http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/05/18/jane-lynch-brings-her-inner-mean-girl-to-glee/|title=Jane Lynch Brings Her Inner Mean Girl to ‘Glee’|last=Itzkoff|first=David|date=May 18, 2009|work=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|accessdate=May 31, 2009}} ===Characterization=== Sue is initially presented as the glee club's "arch-nemesis". Following the [[Pilot (Glee)|pilot episode]], Lynch said she is "pure evil and doesn't hide it",{{cite web|url=http://www.nypost.com/p/blogs/popwrap/item_sbUrfetlC9ck0hU9lqw0eM;jsessionidpi=9918A97B8F5FD78BFB117297FD0F4B98|title=Meet The Cast of 'Glee,' I Did!|last=Wieselman|first=Jarett|date=May 19, 2009|work=[[New York Post]]|publisher=[[News Corporation]]|accessdate=June 1, 2009}} explaining that she was created as a product of Murphy, Brennan and Falchuk's "inner mean girl". Lynch feels that Sue has the ability to be both "horrible and really delightful at the same time",{{cite web|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/online/oscars/2009/09/qa-jane-lynch-might-just-slip-you-a-mickey.html|title=Q&A: Jane Lynch Might Just Slip You a Mickey|last=Spitznagel|first=Eric|date=September 4, 2009|work=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]|publisher=[[Condé Nast Publications]]|accessdate=September 5, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090907120405/http://www.vanityfair.com/online/oscars/2009/09/qa-jane-lynch-might-just-slip-you-a-mickey.html|archivedate=September 7, 2009|df=mdy-all}} assessing that she continually speaks her mind as she enjoys appalling people with the things she says. She encapsulates Sue's world view as being about "power and winning", stating that she will do anything to win. Sue's softer side manifests following the revelation that her sister has Down syndrome. She is depicted as kind and loving towards Jean, though Lynch stated that exploration of Sue's humanity would be limited.{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2009/SHOWBIZ/TV/11/24/unexpected.glee/|title=Stars discuss their unexpected 'Glee' |last=Mineo|first=Andrea|date=November 25, 2009|publisher=[[CNN]]|accessdate=26 November 2009}} Sue is an [[atheist]], but according to Murphy, does not want to be. He explained, "She [is] saying to the world, 'Prove [me] wrong: If God is kindness and love, make me believe in God.'"{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/News/Glee-Grilled-Cheesus-1023969.aspx?rss=news&partnerid=spi&profileid=05|title=Are You There, God? Glee's Twist on Faith|first=Denise|last=Martin|date=October 4, 2010|work=[[TV Guide]]|accessdate=October 5, 2010}} The second-season episode "[[Grilled Cheesus]]" focuses on the characters' differing approaches to religion. Sue lobbies against the performance of spiritual songs in school, engaging in a philosophical argument on the matter with school guidance counselor [[Emma Pillsbury]] ([[Jayma Mays]]), which Murphy describes as the scene he is "most proud to have been involved with in [his] entire career." On the fifth-season episode "[[Puppet Master (Glee)|Puppet Master]]", the reason behind Sue's track suit outfit was revealed. It was because she felt that she never received the respect she deserved as a teacher and even the then [[Principal Figgins]] "insulted" her and said that she was a cheerleading coach so she needed to "try some pants" because she was wearing an office skirt and that she had long hair. She said that the moment she put the track suit on, "the world bowed before her" and that she "had one made in every color". == Musical performances == [[File:Burnett, Carol (Whitehouse).jpg|thumb|right|upright|Sue duets with her mother Doris ([[Carol Burnett]], ''pictured'') during season two.]] Sue performs in several of the series' musical numbers. In the first-season episode "[[Mash-Up (Glee)|Mash-Up]]", she is given a dancing lesson by Will, to [[Louis Prima]]'s "[[Sing, Sing, Sing (With a Swing)]]".{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20421740.html|title=Which Glee Couple Should Be Together?|last=Hefa|first=Kiran|date=November 11, 2009|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|publisher=[[Time Inc.|Time Inc]]|accessdate=December 6, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110807074925/http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20421740.html|archivedate=August 7, 2011|df=mdy-all}} Her first vocal performance comes in the episode "[[The Power of Madonna]]", in which Sue enacts a frame-by-frame recreation of the music video for [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna's]] "[[Vogue (Madonna song)|Vogue]]".{{cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2010/04/14/jane-lynch-takes-on-vogue-video-for-glees-all-madonna-episode/?KEYWORDS=%22Sue+Sylvester%22|title=Jane Lynch Takes On 'Vogue' Video for 'Glee's' All-Madonna Episode|date=April 14, 2010|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|publisher=[[Dow Jones & Company]]|accessdate=February 2, 2011}} The track features on the [[extended play]] record ''[[Glee: The Music, The Power of Madonna]]'', released to accompany the episode,{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Glee-Music-Power-Madonna-Cast/dp/B003AO3CR6/ref=sr_1_5?ie=UTF8&s=music&qid=1283778427&sr=8-5|title=Glee: The Music, The Power Of Madonna |publisher=[[Amazon.com]]|accessdate=September 6, 2010}} and charted at number 106 on the [[UK singles chart]].{{cite journal|title = Official Singles Chart for the week ending 8 May 2010|journal = [[ChartsPlus]]|issue = 454|pages= 1–4|date = May 6, 2010|publisher = UKChartsPlus|location = Liverpool}} Sue duets with [[Olivia Newton-John]] on her song "[[Physical (Olivia Newton-John song)|Physical]]" in the episode "[[Bad Reputation (Glee)|Bad Reputation]]".{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/tvandradioblog/2010/may/06/glee-sue-sylvester-cover-next|title=Who should Glee's Sue Sylvester cover next? |last=Lusher|first=Tim|date=May 6, 2010|work=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]]|accessdate=May 12, 2010}} This track was included on the [[soundtrack album]] ''[[Glee: The Music, Volume 3 Showstoppers]]'',{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Glee-Music-3-Showstoppers-Cast/dp/B003H6Z0PO/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&s=music&qid=1283778427&sr=8-2 |title=Glee: The Music, Volume 3: Showstoppers |work=[[Amazon.com]]|accessdate=September 6, 2010}} as well as the [[compilation album]]s ''Glee: The Music, The Complete Season One'', and ''Glee: The Music, The Complete Season One Collection''.{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/album/glee-the-music-the-complete/id390992006|title=Glee: The Music, The Complete Season One|publisher=[[iTunes Store]]|accessdate=September 14, 2010}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.sanity.com.au/products/2193954/Glee_The_Music_Season_1_Collection|title=Glee The Music; Season 1 Collection|publisher=[[Sanity (music store)|Sanity]]|accessdate=January 29, 2011}} Also released as a single available for [[Music download|download]], it charted both on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] and internationally, peaking at number 89 in the US, 88 in Australia, 61 in Canada and 56 in the United Kingdom.Peak chart positions for "Physical": *US: {{Cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/2010-05-22/hot-100?order=gainer|title=Hot 100: Week of May 22, 2010 (Biggest Jump)|date=May 22, 2010|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Nielsen Business Media]]|accessdate=October 10, 2010}} *Australia: {{cite web|url=http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/23790/20100611-0000/Issue1057.pdf|title=The ARIA Report: Week Commencing 31 May 2010|date=May 31, 2010|publisher=[[Australian Recording Industry
